column2: location= [[Cape Lookout (North Carolina)]], [[Carteret County, North Carolina]]
location= On Core Banks, [[Core Banks, North Carolina]]

column1: The '''Cape Lookout Lighthouse''' is a 163-foot high lighthouse located on the Southern [[Outer Banks]] of [[North Carolina]]. It flashes every 15 seconds and is visible at least 12 miles out to sea and up to 19 miles. The Cape Lookout Light is one of the very few [[lighthouse]]s that operate during the day. It became fully automated in 1950.<ref name=\"Historic\">{{cite uscghist
column3: accessdate=2008-08-17}}</ref> The Cape Lookout Lighthouse is the only such structure in the United States to bear the checkered daymark, intended not only for differentiation between similar light towers, but also to show direction. The center of the black diamonds points in a north-south direction, while the center of the white diamonds points east-west.<ref>{{cite web

column4: View of Cape Lookout Lighthouse from a public beach access on South Core Banks, 2007]]

column1: It is the second lighthouse that has stood at [[Cape Lookout (North Carolina)
column2: this location]], and is nearly identical to the [[Bodie Island Lighthouse]], which has horizontal stripes, and the [[Currituck Beach Lighthouse]], which is unpainted red brick. The more famous [[Cape Hatteras Lighthouse]] bears spiral stripes. The first lighthouse at Cape Lookout was completed and lit in 1812 at a cost of more than $20,000, which Congress authorized in 1804. It took 8 years to build.<ref name=\"nps.gov\">{{cite web
column4: title=Lighthouse History Timeline - Cape Lookout National Seashore (U.S. National Park Service)
column6: accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref> It was the fourth lighthouse to be built in North Carolina and was a 96 foot high brick tower with wooden shingles painted with red and white horizontal stripes. But it proved to be too short to light the treacherous Lookout Shoals, which were nicknamed the \"Horrible Headland.\"<ref name = nrhpinv>{{Cite web
column7: author = Survey and Planning Unit Staff
column9: work = National Register of Historic Places - Nomination and Inventory
column13: publisher = North Carolina State Historic Preservation Office

column1: The present lighthouse was completed and lit on November 1, 1859 at a cost of $45,000, which Congress approved in 1857. This lighthouse used a first-order [[Fresnel lens]] which allowed the light to shine brighter. On May 20, 1861, North Carolina joined the [[Confederate States of America
column2: Confederacy]] and all of the lenses were removed from the coastal lighthouses and navigational beacons to prevent Union forces from using the lights to navigate the coast.  [[Union (American Civil War)
column3: Union]] troops captured the nearby Beaufort and Morehead City in 1862 and, by the end of the next year, a third-order [[Fresnel lens]] was installed in the Cape Lookout lighthouse.  On April 2, 1864, a small group of Confederate troops under the command of L.C. Harland snuck through Union lines and out to the lighthouse. Their attempt to blow up the lighthouse was unsuccessful, however the explosion did destroy the lighthouse oil supply and damaged the iron stairs.  With iron unavailable during the war, the damaged sections of the stairs were replaced by wooden ones.  The Fresnel lenses from all the North Carolina lighthouses were found in 1865 in Raleigh, NC. The lenses were shipped back to their original manufacturers to be checked out and repaired.  In 1867, the temporary wooden stairs were replaced when iron once again became available after the war and the original first-order [[Fresnel lens]] was reinstalled.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=The Cape Lookout Light and the Civil War - Cape Lookout National Seashore (U.S. National Park Service)

column1: In 1873, the lighthouse was painted in its distinctive black and white diagonal checkerboard, or diamond, pattern.<ref name=\"nps.gov\"/>  There are those who believe the Cape Hatteras Light and the Cape Lookout Light paint schemes were reversed. This belief arose since the Cape Hatteras Light protects ships from Diamond Shoals and should therefore have the diamond pattern.<ref>{{cite web
column7: archivedate=2008-05-18 }}</ref> However, the daymark patterns were randomly assigned and there is no evidence to suggest that the Cape Lookout and Cape Hatteras patterns were switched. [[Diamond City, North Carolina
column8: Diamond City]], a community that once stood on the eastern end of [[Shackleford Banks]], was named after the daymark pattern on the nearby Cape Lookout Lighthouse.

column1: The lighthouse is part of the [[Cape Lookout National Seashore]] and can only be accessed by private ferry. During the summer, the Cape Lookout Light Station Visitor Center and Keepers' Quarters Museum are open. Though tower climbs were suspended in February 2008,<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Lighthouse Climbs Suspended For Public Safety - Cape Lookout National Seashore (U.S. National Park Service)
column5: accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref> the lighthouse opened for climbing permanently July 15, 2010. The regular season lasts from mid-May to mid-September each year. During the open season, visitors are allowed to climb the 207 steps to the top of the lighthouse and experience the breath-taking view of Core Banks.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Climbing the Cape Lookout Lighthouse - Cape Lookout National Seashore (U.S. National Park Service)

On the sea side, it has washed away about 100 feet last year by abrasion and sea flows.\"

* In 1851 Cape Lookout Lighthouse was reported as one of nine coast lights \"which require to be improved.  The towers of each of them should have an elevation of 150 feet above the level of the sea and should be fitted up in the best manner with first-order lens apparatus, to insure a brilliancy and range adequate to the wants of commerce. These lights are not sufficiently well distinguished, but a general plan for all the seacoast lights will best accomplish this object.\"

* On March 3, 1857, Congress appropriated $45,000 \"for rebuilding and fitting out with first-order apparatus the lighthouse at Cape Lookout, North Carolina.\" The new lighthouse was completed and first lighted on November 1, 1859. column2: name          = The Hundred and One Dalmatians
image         = File:Dodie Smith 101 Dalmatians book cover.jpg

column1: '''''The Hundred and One Dalmatians''''' is a 1956 children's novel by [[Dodie Smith]] about the kidnapping of a family of Dalmatian puppies. It was originally serialized in ''[[Woman's Day]]'' as ''The Great Dog Robbery''.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='101 Dalmatians' and Breed Popularity in the U.S.
column11: access-date=}}</ref> A sequel, ''[[The Starlight Barking]]'', continues from the end of the novel.

column2: dinner party]] attended by the Dearly couple, [[Cruella de Vil]] expresses her dislike for animals; subsequently, the couple's new [[Dalmatian dog
column3: Dalmatian]] puppies disappear. The Dearly dogs are now among 97 puppies who were kidnapped or legally purchased from various owners, with the intention of skinning them for their [[fur]]. Through the co-operation of animals and the \"Twilight barking\", the dogs are found in [[Suffolk]], England, and a rescue ensues.

column1: Pongo and Missis are a pair of [[Dalmatian (dog)
column2: Dalmatian]]s who live with the newly married Mr. and Mrs. Dearly and their two nannies, Nanny Cook and Nanny Butler. Mr. Dearly is a \"financial wizard\" who has been granted lifelong tax exemption and lent a house on the Outer Circle in [[Regent's Park]] in return for wiping out the [[government debt]]. The dogs consider the humans their pets, but allow the humans to think that they are the owners.

column1: Missis gives birth to a litter of 15 puppies. Concerned that Missis will not be able to feed them all, the humans join in to help. As Mrs. Dearly looks for a canine [[wet nurse]], she finds an exhausted liver-spotted Dalmatian in the middle of the road in the pouring rain. She has the dog treated by a vet, learns that she has recently given birth, and names her Perdita (meaning \"lost\"). Perdita helps to nurse the pups and becomes a member of the family, later telling Pongo about her lost love Prince and the resulting litter of puppies which were sold by her owner, and that she had run away looking for those puppies.

One day, while walking Pongo and Missis, Mr. and Mrs. Dearly have a chance meeting with an old schoolmate of Mrs. Dearly: Cruella de Vil, a very wealthy woman so fixated on fur clothing that she married a furrier and forces him to keep his fur collection in their home so she can wear the pieces whenever she likes. She admires the two dogs and expresses a desire to have a Dalmatian-skin coat. She happens to be in the house when the puppies start to arrive, and offers to buy them all. They refuse, and shortly after that the puppies disappear. The humans fail to trace them but through the \"Twilight Barking\", a forum of communication in which dogs can relay messages to each other across the country, the dogs track them down to \"Hell Hall\", the ancestral home of the de Vil family in [[Suffolk]]. Pongo and Missis try to tell the Dearlys where the puppies are but fail: Pongo tried to say the human word \"Suffolk\" but could not make the \"s\" sound. The dogs decide to find the puppies themselves, leaving Perdita to look after the Dearlys. After an eventful journey across the English countryside, with food and accommodation along the way arranged by dogs through the Barking Network, they meet the Colonel, an [[Old English Sheepdog]] at [[Withermarsh]] in Suffolk; he shows them Hell Hall and tells them its history. They get inside the mansion and discover that there are 97 puppies in Hell Hall, including Pongo and Missis' own 15.

Cruella de Vil arrives and tells the two crooks in charge of Hell Hall that they must slaughter and skin the dogs as soon as possible because of the publicity surrounding the theft of the Dearlys' puppies. Pongo and Missis realize they must rescue all of the puppies immediately and they escape the night before Christmas Eve. One puppy, Cadpig, is a [[runt]] and too weak to walk the long distance from Suffolk to London so Tommy, the Colonel's two-year-old owner, lends her a toy farm cart; one of the litters of puppies is just the right age for two of its members to fit its shaft, so they pull it in shifts. When Cruella returns to find the puppies gone, she begins to pursue them. However, the Dalmatians have encountered one of the Barking Network dogs, who points out how conspicuous they are and helps them break into a chimney sweep's establishment where they roll in [[soot]] to disguise themselves. Cruella nearly catches up with them, but they are able to hide in an empty removal van at the invitation of a [[Staffordshire Bull Terrier
column2: Staffordshire terrier]] whose \"pets\" own the van—which is returning to London that very night.

column1: Upon arriving in London, the dogs destroy the de Vils' collection of animal skins and fur coats with the help of Cruella's cat, who was angry and distressed at losing many litters of kittens which Cruella had drowned. The Dalmatians then return to the Dearlys' house, where Pongo and Missis bark until Mr. Dearly opens the door, whereupon the whole mass of puppies go streaming in without stopping. Once the dogs roll on the carpet to remove the soot from their coats, the Dearlys recognise them and send out for steaks to feed them. The litter that pulled Cadpig's cart proved to be Perdita's litter by Prince. Mr. Dearly finds out where the puppies had been when he discovers a label on the toy cart which contains Tommy's name and address. The Dearlys also place advertisements seeking the owners of the other puppies, but it turns out that they had all been sold, rather than stolen as the Dearlys' were.

Cruella's now-homeless cat drops by (and is invited to stay) with the news that the destruction of her husband's fur business has forced Cruella to put Hell Hall up for sale. When the Dearlys visit Suffolk to return Tommy's cart, they realize that, with 97 puppies, and three adult Dalmatians, a larger home would be a good idea, so Mr Dearly buys the hall with money he has been given by the government for sorting out another tax problem. He proposes to use it to start a \"dynasty of Dalmatians\" (and a \"dynasty of Dearlys\" to take care of them). Finally, Perdita's lost love, Prince, turns up. His owners see his love for Perdita and allow him to stay with the Dearlys and become their \"one hundred and oneth\" Dalmatian.

column2: Disney]] adapted the novel into an [[animated film]], released to cinemas on 25 January 1961 as ''[[One Hundred and One Dalmatians]]''. It became the tenth highest-grossing film of 1961,<ref name=\"Gebert\">{{Cite book
column10: date=September 2010}}</ref> and one of the studio's most popular films of the decade. It was re-issued to cinemas four times, in 1969, 1979, 1985 and 1991. The 1991 reissue was the twentieth highest earning film of the year for domestic earnings. It was remade into [[101 Dalmatians (1996 film)
column11: a live action movie]] years later.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: In both the live-action and animated adaptations, Missis was renamed Perdita, and other characters, such as Prince, Tommy, Cruella's cat, and Cruella's husband were omitted. In the animated film, Pongo and Missis' owners' last names were changed to \"Radcliffe\" from \"Dearly\", and in the live-action film, Cruella (portrayed by [[Glenn Close]]) appears as the spoiled magnate of an haute couture fashion house, \"''House of DeVil''\". Disney kept the book's characters Horace and Jasper Baddun, who appeared in both versions as thieves hired by Cruella to steal Pongo and Missis' puppies. (In the novel, their names are Saul and Jasper Baddun.) Disney later created an [[101 Dalmatians: The Series
column2: animated television series]] starring three of the puppies (Lucky, Rolly and Cadpig) and a sequel film for each version (''[[101 Dalmatians II: Patch's London Adventure
column3: One Hundred and One Dalmatians II]]'' and ''[[102 Dalmatians]]'').

column1: The novel has been adapted for the stage by [[Debbie Isitt]] for the [[Belgrade Theatre
column2: Belgrade Theatre, Coventry]] in 2000 (followed by productions at the [[Royal & Derngate
column3: Royal & Derngate, Northampton]] in 2007 and [[Birmingham Repertory Theatre]] in 2017), by [[Bryony Lavery]] for the Chichester Youth Theatre in 2014 and was devised by the company (directed by Sally Cookson) for [[Tobacco Factory Theatre]]s in 2014. The novel was also adapted into a [[101 Dalmatians Musical
column4: 2009 musical]] and will be adapted into an upcoming [[101 Dalmatians (2020 musical)

column1: '''Brian Reynolds''' (born 1967) is an American [[videogame designer]] who now designs online social games (e.g. on Facebook). Reynolds has designed at SecretNewCo, [[Zynga]], [[Big Huge Games]], [[Firaxis Games]], and [[MicroProse]] and has been chairman of the [[International Game Developers Association]]. He has played a major part in designing a number of multi-million selling games including ''[[Civilization II]]'', ''[[Rise of Nations]]'', ''[[Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri]]'', and ''[[FrontierVille]]''. He has also founded or co-founded three game companies, SecretNewCo, Big Huge Games, and Firaxis Games.

Reynolds made his first game sale with [[Quest 1]] to ''[[SoftSide]]'' magazine, its August 1981 cover feature. He was a gamer in high school, and a [[SysOp]] on [[Randolph School]]'s ([[Huntsville, Alabama]]) [[PDP-11]] [[mainframe computer]].<ref>Walden, Lea Ann, et al. (Spring 2013). \"[http://content.yudu.com/Library/A28edh/RandolphMagazineSpri/resources/index.htm?referrerUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.randolphschool.net%2Fpodium%2Fdefault.aspx%3Ft%3D149781%26uplid%3D431684260%26rc%3D0 Where Are They Now?]\". [http://www.randolphschool.net/R/publications Randolph Magazine] {{webarchive
column3: date=2014-08-27 }} 18 (1). pp. 20-27. Retrieved August 26, 2014.</ref> A 1990 graduate of the [[Sewanee: The University of the South
column4: University of the South]], Reynolds briefly pursued graduate studies in [[Philosophy]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].{{cn

column1: Reynolds initiated his game career with [[MicroProse]] where he worked as lead programmer for a number of [[Adventure game
column2: graphic adventure games]]. These included ''[[Rex Nebular and the Cosmic Gender Bender
column3: Rex Nebular]]'' in [[1992 in video gaming
column4: 1992]] and ''[[Return of the Phantom]]'' and ''[[Dragonsphere]]'' in [[1993 in video gaming

column1: It was at MicroProse where Reynolds first worked with [[Sid Meier]] and the two collaborated on a strategy title by the name of ''[[Colonization (computer game)
column2: Sid Meier's Colonization]]'' which was released in [[1994 in video gaming
column3: 1994]]. Reynolds went on to become lead designer for a sequel to ''[[Civilization (computer game)
column4: Sid Meier's Civilization]]''. ''[[Civilization II]]'' was released in [[1996 in video gaming

column1: While at Firaxis, Reynolds contributed to ''[[Sid Meier's Gettysburg]]'' in [[1997 in video gaming
column2: 1997]], followed by the creation and design of ''[[Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri]]'' in [[1998 in video gaming
column3: 1998]]. Alpha Centauri became his second multi-million selling title. In [[2000 in video gaming
column4: 2000]] Reynolds left Firaxis games and sold his share in the company to become [[Chief executive officer

column1: On June 30, 2009, [[Zynga]] announced that Brian Reynolds was leaving [[Big Huge Games]] to lead the formation of Zynga East, and serve the role of Chief Game Designer.
In February 2013, Reynolds left Zynga. In March, he revived Big Huge Games (temporarily known as SecretNewCo).<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=September 1, 2015}}</ref> In July, the team announced their partnership with [[Nexon Co. Ltd.

column1: Although marketed under Sid Meier's name, ''Civilization II'', ''Sid Meier's Colonization'' and ''Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri'' all credited Reynolds as lead designer. The credits for ''Civilization II'' only list Meier as the designer of the original ''Civilization'' game, and Reynolds stated in an interview that for this game Meier \"was no longer involved except in name.\"<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=September 3, 2013}}</ref> The credits for ''Alpha Centauri'' state that the game was \"Created by\" Brian Reynolds and Meier is listed with several other team members on the \"With\" line - in the Designers Notes in the game manual Reynolds also thanks him for all his sage advice.

column1: Brian Reynolds' first major break was the design of ''Sid Meier's Civilization II''. Meier had created ''Civilization'' but had moved on to other projects.  MicroProse wanted to make a sequel and asked Reynolds to design it. MicroProse put Meier on retainer for consultational advice and for the use of his name, but Meier only had peripheral involvement in the design of this game. The sequel game, hence, was primarily designed by Reynolds.
''[[Rise of Nations]]'' was Reynolds' first game at Big Huge Games. Later came ''[[Rise of Nations: Rise of Legends
column2: Rise of Legends]]'', a real-time strategy game, [[video game publisher

[...] Klaus Teuber, the designer of both the board game and Xbox Live version, believes that Mr. Reynolds' assistance has led to very challenging AI opponents}}</ref>

'''Brian Reynolds''' (born 1967) is an American [[videogame designer]] who now designs online social games (e.g. on Facebook). Reynolds has designed at SecretNewCo, [[Zynga]], [[Big Huge Games]], [[Firaxis Games]], and [[MicroProse]] and has been chairman of the [[International Game Developers Association]]. He has played a major part in designing a number of multi-million selling games including ''[[Civilization II]]'', ''[[Rise of Nations]]'', ''[[Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri]]'', and ''[[FrontierVille]]''. He has also founded or co-founded three game companies, SecretNewCo, Big Huge Games, and Firaxis Games.

Reynolds made his first game sale with [[Quest 1]] to ''[[SoftSide]]'' magazine, its August 1981 cover feature. He was a gamer in high school, and a [[SysOp]] on [[Randolph School]]'s ([[Huntsville, Alabama]]) [[PDP-11]] [[mainframe computer]].<ref>Walden, Lea Ann, et al. (Spring 2013). \"[http://content.yudu.com/Library/A28edh/RandolphMagazineSpri/resources/index.htm?referrerUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.randolphschool.net%2Fpodium%2Fdefault.aspx%3Ft%3D149781%26uplid%3D431684260%26rc%3D0 Where Are They Now?]\". [http://www.randolphschool.net/R/publications Randolph Magazine] {{webarchive
column3: date=2014-08-27 }} 18 (1). pp. 20-27. Retrieved August 26, 2014.</ref> A 1990 graduate of the [[Sewanee: The University of the South
column4: University of the South]], Reynolds briefly pursued graduate studies in [[Philosophy]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].{{cn

column1: Reynolds initiated his game career with [[MicroProse]] where he worked as lead programmer for a number of [[Adventure game
column2: graphic adventure games]]. These included ''[[Rex Nebular and the Cosmic Gender Bender
column3: Rex Nebular]]'' in [[1992 in video gaming
column4: 1992]] and ''[[Return of the Phantom]]'' and ''[[Dragonsphere]]'' in [[1993 in video gaming

column1: It was at MicroProse where Reynolds first worked with [[Sid Meier]] and the two collaborated on a strategy title by the name of ''[[Colonization (computer game)
column2: Sid Meier's Colonization]]'' which was released in [[1994 in video gaming
column3: 1994]]. Reynolds went on to become lead designer for a sequel to ''[[Civilization (computer game)
column4: Sid Meier's Civilization]]''. ''[[Civilization II]]'' was released in [[1996 in video gaming

column1: While at Firaxis, Reynolds contributed to ''[[Sid Meier's Gettysburg]]'' in [[1997 in video gaming
column2: 1997]], followed by the creation and design of ''[[Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri]]'' in [[1998 in video gaming
column3: 1998]]. Alpha Centauri became his second multi-million selling title. In [[2000 in video gaming
column4: 2000]] Reynolds left Firaxis games and sold his share in the company to become [[Chief executive officer

column1: On June 30, 2009, [[Zynga]] announced that Brian Reynolds was leaving [[Big Huge Games]] to lead the formation of Zynga East, and serve the role of Chief Game Designer.
In February 2013, Reynolds left Zynga. In March, he revived Big Huge Games (temporarily known as SecretNewCo).<ref>{{cite web
column4: accessdate=September 1, 2015}}</ref> In July, the team announced their partnership with [[Nexon Co. Ltd.

Information about her early life before she started her career.,safe,OMcL,"'''Marion R. Buller''' (also known as Marion Buller Bennett) is a [[First Nations]] jurist in [[British Columbia]].  Judge Buller served as the Chief Commissioner for the [[Missing and murdered Indigenous women#National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women
column2: National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls]].<ref name=cbc>{{cite news
column4: title=Marion Buller, B.C. First Nations judge, to lead MMIW inquiry
column12: title=Female indigenous judge to lead probe into missing, murdered women
column20: title=Marion Buller, Head Of MMIW Inquiry, Has Been Touched Personally By Tragedy

column1: A member of the [[Mistawasis First Nation]],<ref name=star/><ref name=cl/><ref name=huffpo/> she was the first First Nations woman to be appointed to the [[Provincial Court of British Columbia]] in 1994,<ref name=cbc/><ref name=uvic>{{cite web
and presided in courts throughout B.C.<ref name=cl/>
She established the First Nations Courts of British Columbia in 2006<ref name=cbc/><ref name=huffpo/>
and provided the foundation for the Aboriginal Family Healing Court in 2016.
Buller served as President of the Indigenous Bar Association and served as Director of the B.C. Law Court Society, B.C.  Law Foundation, B.C. Police Commission and the B.C. Mediators Roster.
Buller has lectured and written numerous articles and papers about Aboriginal law, criminal law, family law and human rights.

Marion Buller was born in 1953 in Toronto, Ontario. She is a member of the Mistawasis' First Nations although she did not grow up on the reserve because of discriminatory sections of the Indian Act from that time, she instead was raised in Toronto. Throughout her childhood she maintained a close relationship with her indigenous grandparents even though she did not grow up on the reserve, they taught her their traditional teachings that played a major part in her life while growing up. From a young age a strong work ethic was instilled into her, she learned cooking, cleaning, sewing and outside work from both her mother and father. In her life, work was not a “woman’s or man’s” job but you had to work hard to be considered equal to others. As both a woman and an indigenous woman she was taught that she would have to work even harder than most to get to the places she needed to be. Education was expected in her family, and she was taught that girls are entitled to the same education as boys received.

She was not always aiming for a career in law, at first she wanted a career in a museum. After she finished her BA in Anthropology at the University of Victoria she went to work in the private sector, but because of the job market at the time, she knew she would need some sort of post-graduate degree. She decided to do Law at the University of Victoria so moving was not required. At first she thought she might go into Business Law, but while in first year she took Criminal Law with Dr. Keith Jobson and from that point forward knew she needed to be in the courtroom.

Marion cannot pinpoint in her life when or how she became a feminist. Her upbringing taught her to believe in equality and equity but also the world’s shortcomings of inequality and equity that must be corrected.
“I learned these lessons not just by words, but by the examples set by my family  members.”
Judge Marion Buller attended the [[University of Victoria]] where she received a [[Bachelor of Arts
column2: BA]] in [[Anthropology]] in 1975 and later graduated with her [[Bachelor of Laws
column3: LLB]] in 1987. Buller’s career in law was nothing far from noteworthy; she was instrumental in facilitating several organizations regarding indigenous rights, women’s rights, Aboriginal law, family law and human rights.  From 1988-1994, Buller worked as a [[civil law (common law)
column5: criminal]] lawyer in British Columbia<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=Honourable Marion Buller - University of Victoria
column10: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref>. In 1994, Buller was appointed to the [[Provincial and territorial courts in Canada
column11: Provincial Court]] bench, making her the first female indigenous Judge in British Columbia.

column1: During her legal career, Buller worked as both president and director of Canada’s Indigenous Bar Association; a national nonprofit association of [[First Nations]], [[Métis]], and [[Inuit]] persons in Canada trained in the field of law. Membership includes judges, lawyers, political leaders, academics, articling and law students<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref>.  She also has been an active member of several other organizations such as the B.C. Police Commission, the BC Mediators’ Roster, the Law Foundation of B.C. and the Law Courts Education Society - a nonprofit organization that provides educational programs and services regarding the justice system in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title=Law Courts Education Society of BC
column11: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref> Among the many other milestones mentioned of Buller’s career, in 2006, she was established the First Nations Court of British Columbia; a criminal sentencing court which uses restorative justice and traditional ways to reach balance and healing.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=First Nations Court {{!}} Aboriginal Legal Aid in BC
column15: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref>  Judge Buller also developed the foundation for the Aboriginal Family Healing Court, a Court to address the return of Indigenous children to their families.  Judge Buller has written notable papers and articles which aimed to highlight the inconsistencies within the Justice System regarding [[Indigenous rights
column16: indigenous rights, women’s rights]], [[Canadian Aboriginal law
column17: Aboriginal law]], etc. She has also worked as the Commission Counsel for the [[Cariboo-Chilcotin Justice Inquiry]] which examined the relationship between the [[Cariboo-Chilcotin (provincial electoral district)
column18: Cariboo-Chilcotin]] people and the justice system.<ref>{{Cite news
column20: title=Judge, lawyers among commissioners expected to be named to missing, murdered inquiry

column1: In 2016, Buller retired from her position as Judge at the [[Provincial Court of British Columbia
column2: Provincial Court of British Columbia.]] After retiring from her successful career in the field of law, Judge Buller went on to be appointed as Chief Commissioner for the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls; the first truly national inquiry.  The National Inquiry examined the systemic causes of all forms of violence against indigenous women and girls, including sexual violence.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Our Mandate, Our Vision, Our Mission {{!}} MMIWG
column10: access-date=2020-03-23}}</ref> As Chief Commissioner of the organization, Buller played a major role in the writing of ''Reclaiming Power and Place: The Final Report'' of the [[Missing and murdered Indigenous women
column11: National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls]];  a comprehensive two-volume report which examines the causes for the disturbing statistics of violence against Indigenous women, girls and 2SLGBTQQIA people in Canada<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=Our Mandate, Our Vision, Our Mission {{!}} MMIWG

column1: Besides being appointed the first woman First Nations judge in British Columbia, Marion Buller has accomplished a multitude of great things. In 2012, Buller received the Distinguished Alumni Award from the University of Victoria Faculty of Social Science.<ref name=\"uvic\"/> In 2016, [[Maclean's]] listed her as one of only six people who might be especially influential on policy in the [[29th Canadian Ministry
column3: title=The Liberals forge ahead: Six people to watch
column6: url=http://www.macleans.ca/politics/ottawa/the-liberals-forge-ahead-six-people-to-watch/}}</ref>. Buller has received numerous other awards, including the Queen's Golden Jubilee which recognizes Albertans who demonstrate leadership and talent in performing and visual arts. <ref>[https://www.alberta.ca/queens-golden-jubilee-awards.aspx \"Queen's Golden Jubilee Awards\"]</ref> She also received a Diamond Jubilee Medal which acknowledges Canadian citizens who have greatly contributed to the country and brought great credit to Canada. <ref>[https://www.canada.ca/en/department-national-defence/services/medals/medals-chart-index/queen-elizabeth-ii-diamond-jubilee-medal.html \"Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee Medal\"] </ref> Finally, Marion Buller received the Rosemary Brown Award for Women. This award recognizes a British Columbia based woman who upholds the values and ideals of which Rosemary Brown did during her life.<ref>[https://summit.sfu.ca/item/10659 \"Rosemary Brown Award for Women.\"]</ref> Rosemary Brown was an accomplished Canadian politician who contributed greatly to British Columbia<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosemary_Brown_(politician) \"Rosemary Brown (Politician)\"]</ref>

column2: known_for     = Revolutionizing the sound and showmanship of the violin and the World's only Gold Phoenix Violinist

column1: '''Dennis Lau''' (born 9 September 1985) is an award-winning [[Malaysian people
column4: producer]] that is based in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]].

column1: Lau was born and raised in [[Ipoh]] where he lived there for 8 years before permanently moving to Kuala Lumpur. At that time, he studied in [[SRJK(C) San Min]]. His first exposure to music began at the age of 3 with the piano, under the guidance of his mother Chuah Chai Eng, who is a pianist herself. When he turned 11, Lau became the youngest in Malaysia to reach Grade 8 in the ABRSM graded piano exam.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=From Fire and Ashes, Dennis Lau Rises

column1: Lau also took up violin lessons on the side when he was 8 years old, under the tutelage of prominent violin instructors in Malaysia, [[Nora Kim]] and the late [[Andrew Chye]]. By the age of 15, he obtained the [[Trinity College London
column2: ATCL]] [[Diploma]], and within the following years, he was awarded for his outstanding performance for his [[LTCL]] and [[FTCL]] exams.

column1: After secondary studies, he decided to further his education in music, citing that he was “bad in his academics” and since his interests gravitated more towards the arts, “music was the only thing” that he could “pass”.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Violinist Dennis Lau is simply electric

column1: He attended [[UCSI University]] for his tertiary studies and graduated in 2006 with a B.A in Music under the [[Newcastle Australian Music Degree Programme]], with a Double Major in [[Piano]] and [[Violin]].

At that time, Lau was also actively involved as a regular [[secessionist]] with the [[RTM Orchestra]] and the [[National Symphony Orchestra]]. He also held the first violin position for the [[Malaysian Philharmonic Orchestra]] (MPYO).

During his second year, Lau was already frequently playing the violin in hotel lounges and took part in a bit of acting on the side. By his third year, he started composing his own songs and initiated more collaborations with local artistes, which contributed to his popularity.

Lau quickly became well-known for his frequent appearances in high profile events and functions as a performer. Apart from playing at launches of well-known brands, he also performed for [[Dato’ Sri Khalid bin Mohamad Jiwa]] and [[Dato’ Siti Nurhaliza]]’s first wedding anniversary in 2007.
In 2007 itself, he founded [[Mosaic Entertainment Group]], a platform that offers artistes the chance to showcase their talent by giving them the opportunity to perform at various functions.

In November 2009, Lau launched his maiden album titled [[DiversiFy]], which won an award for Best Producer. [[Sony Music Entertainment]] signed Lau on and took on the role as distributors of DiversiFy — this made Lau the first instrumental artiste to be signed on with Sony in the whole nation.

Lau also made a guest appearance in [[Star World’s Asia Uncut Programme]] hosted by [[Jon Niermann]] in [[Shanghai]]. On top of that, he also had his first collaboration with an international artiste when he performed with [[David Tao]] during his ‘Love Can’ concert.
Eventually, Lau was travelling around the world to perform at various functions in the presence of notable public figures.
* First music video shot for his number [[Prelude in F Minor]].
* Release of [[DiversiFy Limited Edition]] in November.
* Sony Music gave the opportunity to open for [[Adam Lambert]] during his Asia tour.
* Collaboration with [[DJ Bass Agents]] in [[Crown Casino Melbourne]] for one of the biggest 2011 [[Merdeka]] Celebrations.
* Performed at the [[Islamic Fashion Festival]] in [[London]], [[Singapore]] and [[Kuala Lumpur]] where he played in the presence of [[Stella McCartney]] as well as the [[Princess of Monaco]].
* Made his film debut in [[Namewee]]’s [[Nasi Lemak 2.0]] and starred as Lan Qiao.
* Special performance by Invitation for Her Majesty, [[Seri Paduka Baginda Raja Permaisuri Agong Tuanku Nur Zahirah]] in [[Istana Terengganu]] in Kuala Lumpur.
* Performed for the [[Installation Ceremony of the King]] ([[Majlis Santapan Di-Raja]]) at [[Istana Negara, Jalan Duta
* Performed during the royal visit by the [[Duke and Duchess of Cambridge]], [[Prince William]] and [[Kate Middleton]] in the palace of the King in Malaysia.
* Performed as a guest artist for [[MC Jin]] in ‘My Dream’ concert live in Kuala Lumpur
* Won his first award in the [[Prestige Top 40 Under 40]]
* Opening act for [[Miyavi]] live in Kuala Lumpur

* Released music video for [[Gotcha Style]] which features collaboration with well-known artistes such as Moots of [[Pop Shuvit]], [[Thanuja Ananthan]] the [[Miss World Malaysia]] 2009 as well as fashion creator [[Bernard Chandran]].
* Starred in Namewee’s second film [[Hantu Gangster]].
* Won the [[Rising Star awards]] for [[Outstanding Performance Artiste of the Year]] during the [[McMillan Woods Global Awards]].
* Recorded a single with [[Soo Wincci]] titled ‘Don’t You Wanna Know’.

* Launched an album titled [[‘The Malaysian Journey’]] initiated by the [[Jabatan Kementerian Kesenian Negara]] (JKKN) which features Malay classic songs performed by renowned local artistes such as [[Ning Baizura]], [[David Arumugam]] and more.
* Worked with LA-based [[Singaporean]] [[record producer]] [[Tat Tong]] and released another album titled [[‘The Journey’]].
* Won several awards from [[Malaysia Book of Records]], [[McMillan Woods Global Awards]], [[Global Branding Awards]], [[Selangor Excellence Business Awards]], as well as [[Asia Pacific CSR Awards]].
* Was selected by [[MATRADE]] as one of the delegates to attend the [[Marché International du Disque et de l'Edition Musicale (MIDEM)]] conference in [[Cannes]].
* Customised a 23k gold electric violin in a shape of a phoenix with Alistair Hay the founder of [[Emerald Guitars]] who crafted [[Wang Lee Hom]]'s dragon guitar.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Epic adventure brings Malaysian musician to Donegal

column1: * Held his first ever large-scale concert [[Dennis Lau & Friends — The Phoenix Rising Concert]] which features various local artistes that he has previously collaborated with over the years.
* His single [[‘The Destination’]] featuring [[Esmond Chong]] hit number one on the Malaysian [[Hitz.Fm]] [[MET10 charts]].
* Performed at the [[Hong Kong Handover Ceremony Anniversary]] alongside [[Wong Cho-lam]] and [[Mag Lam]].
* Currently working on a collaboration with award-winning producer [[Hanjin Tan]] for his upcoming music video titled ‘Lafite’.
* Charity concert ‘Hope & Smile’ organised by [[Dato Lee Chong Wei]] and [[A/X Loves Japan]]
* Don’t You Wanna Know featuring Soo Wincci (2015)
* 2014 - The BrandLaureate Grand Master Brand ICON Leadership Award 2014
* 2015 - Most Music Collaboration by an Instrumentalist
* 2015 - Global Music Entrepreneur Icon Of The Year Award (Masterclass Category)
* 2015 - Selangor Excellence Business Awards 2015 (Industry Class in Music & Entertainment)
* 2015 - Asia Pacific CSR Awards (Masterclass Socially Responsible Entrepreneur in Music & Entertainment)
On March 14, 2016, Lau proposed to his longtime girlfriend, Yenni Chow, a real estate agent. The couple has been dating for more than 10 years.

column2: known_for     = Revolutionizing the sound and showmanship of the violin and the World's only Gold Phoenix Violinist

column1: '''Dennis Lau''' (born 9 September 1985) is an award-winning [[Malaysian people
column4: producer]] that is based in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]].

column1: Lau was born and raised in [[Ipoh]] where he lived there for 8 years before permanently moving to Kuala Lumpur. At that time, he studied in [[SRJK(C) San Min]]. His first exposure to music began at the age of 3 with the piano, under the guidance of his mother Chuah Chai Eng, who is a pianist herself. When he turned 11, Lau became the youngest in Malaysia to reach Grade 8 in the ABRSM graded piano exam.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=From Fire and Ashes, Dennis Lau Rises

column1: Lau also took up violin lessons on the side when he was 8 years old, under the tutelage of prominent violin instructors in Malaysia, [[Nora Kim]] and the late [[Andrew Chye]]. By the age of 15, he obtained the [[Trinity College London
column2: ATCL]] [[Diploma]], and within the following years, he was awarded for his outstanding performance for his [[LTCL]] and [[FTCL]] exams.

column1: After secondary studies, he decided to further his education in music, citing that he was “bad in his academics” and since his interests gravitated more towards the arts, “music was the only thing” that he could “pass”.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Violinist Dennis Lau is simply electric

column1: He attended [[UCSI University]] for his tertiary studies and graduated in 2006 with a B.A in Music under the [[Newcastle Australian Music Degree Programme]], with a Double Major in [[Piano]] and [[Violin]].

At that time, Lau was also actively involved as a regular [[secessionist]] with the [[RTM Orchestra]] and the [[National Symphony Orchestra]]. He also held the first violin position for the [[Malaysian Philharmonic Orchestra]] (MPYO).

During his second year, Lau was already frequently playing the violin in hotel lounges and took part in a bit of acting on the side. By his third year, he started composing his own songs and initiated more collaborations with local artistes, which contributed to his popularity.

Lau quickly became well-known for his frequent appearances in high profile events and functions as a performer. Apart from playing at launches of well-known brands, he also performed for [[Dato’ Sri Khalid bin Mohamad Jiwa]] and [[Dato’ Siti Nurhaliza]]’s first wedding anniversary in 2007.
In 2007 itself, he founded [[Mosaic Entertainment Group]], a platform that offers artistes the chance to showcase their talent by giving them the opportunity to perform at various functions.

In November 2009, Lau launched his maiden album titled [[DiversiFy]], which won an award for Best Producer. [[Sony Music Entertainment]] signed Lau on and took on the role as distributors of DiversiFy — this made Lau the first instrumental artiste to be signed on with Sony in the whole nation.

Lau also made a guest appearance in [[Star World’s Asia Uncut Programme]] hosted by [[Jon Niermann]] in [[Shanghai]]. On top of that, he also had his first collaboration with an international artiste when he performed with [[David Tao]] during his ‘Love Can’ concert.
Eventually, Lau was travelling around the world to perform at various functions in the presence of notable public figures.
* First music video shot for his number [[Prelude in F Minor]].
* Release of [[DiversiFy Limited Edition]] in November.

column1: The '''1991 FIFA Women's World Cup Final''' was a [[Association football
column2: football]] match that took place on 30 November 1991 at [[Tianhe Stadium]] in [[Guangzhou]], [[China]]. It was played between [[Norway women's national football team
column3: Norway]] and the [[United States women's national soccer team
column4: United States]] to determine the winner of the [[1991 FIFA Women's World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=FIFA Women's World Cup – China PR 1991
column9: accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref> The United States beat Norway 2–1, with two goals from [[Michelle Akers
column10: Michelle Akers-Stahl]], to become winners of the first ever [[FIFA Women's World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Combating a myth from Women's World Cup '91
column20: title=American women in final in soccer

column1: The final was contested by [[Norway women's national football team
column2: Norway]], who rebounded from a stunning 4–0 defeat by host nation [[China women's national football team
column3: China PR]] to qualify from their group. They then dispatched [[Italy women's national football team
column4: Italy]] and historic rivals [[Sweden women's national football team
column5: Sweden]] in the knockout rounds to reach the final. The other team in the final was the [[United States women's national soccer team
column6: United States]], who went undefeated throughout the competition, thrashing highly rated [[Germany women's national football team
column10: title=Soccer; U.S. women beat Norway to capture World Cup
column17: title=Sports Weekend; U.S. women's soccer team's message: 'No one will get in our way'

column2: occupation    = [[Indian independence activist]], social reformer, poet

column1: '''Bodheswaran''' (December 28, 1901 – July 3, 1990), (also known as '''Bodheswarananda'''), was an [[Indian independence activist]], social reformer and a poet of [[Malayalam literature]]. He was known for his nationalistic poems such as ''Keralaganam'' and for his involvement in social movements like [[Vaikom Satyagraha]] and other related events which led to the [[Temple Entry Proclamation]] of 1936.

Bodheswaran, née Keshava Pilla, was born on December 28, 1901 in [[Neyyattinkara]], in [[Travancore]] (in the present day [[Thiruvananthapuram]], [[Kerala]], India) to Champayil veettil Kunjan Pilla and Thazhamangalam Janaki Pilla.<ref name=\"Biography on Kerala Sahitya Akademi portal\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Biography on Kerala Sahitya Akademi portal
column6: access-date=2019-04-08}}</ref> Influenced by the thoughts of [[Swami Vivekananda]] from an early age, he left his studies to visit the social and religious reformer [[Narayana Guru]] with whom he stayed for about two years.<ref name=\"Bodheswaran -  Veethi profile\">{{Cite web
column11: access-date=2019-04-08}}</ref> Subsequently, he travelled throughout India and during a visit to the [[Kashi Vishwanath Temple]], he assumed the name of Bodheswarananda. It was during these travels, he met several [[Sannyasins]] and Indian independence activists; he also had the opportunity to attend the public meetings of [[Mohandas K. Gandhi]] and [[Motilal Nehru]].<ref name=\"Chattampi Swami: An Intellectual Biography\">{{Cite book

column1: Bodheswaran was married to V. K. Karthyayani, a professor of Sanskrit in the [[Government Sanskrit College, Thiruvananthapuram]].<ref name=ThanuLalita1993p399>{{cite book
column2: title=Women Writing in India: The twentieth century
column4: series=Women Writing in India: 600 B.C. to the Present
column14: accessdate=2011-10-11}}</ref> The couple had three daughters, [[:ml:ഹൃദയകുമാരി
column15: Hridayakumari]], [[Sugathakumari]] and Sujatha, all the three being noted writers.<ref name=\"Bodheswaran - Kerala Literature\">{{Cite web
column20: access-date=2019-04-08}}</ref><ref name=\"About Author Sujatha Devi\">{{Cite web
column25: access-date=2019-04-09}}</ref> He died on July 3, 1990, at the age of 88.<ref name=\"Biography on Kerala Sahitya Akademi portal\" />

column1: On his return to Kerala, Bodheswaran was advised by Narayana Guru to meet [[Chattampi Swamikal]], who was known to have been a major influence in his life.<ref name=\"Bodheswaran -  Veethi profile\" /> Thereafter, he kept his association with Swamikal, while getting involved the [[Indian freedom struggle]] and made several public speeches which were saide to have attracted large crowds.<ref name=\"Chattampi Swami: An Intellectual Biography\" /> After a short spell during which he favoured the [[Arya Samaj]] movement, he got involved in the [[Vaikom Satyagraha]] and other related events until the [[Temple Entry Proclamation]] of 1936.<ref name=\"Bodheswaran -  Veethi profile\" /> He also became a member of the [[Indian National Congress]] and changed his name once more, to Bodheswaran.<ref name=\"Chattampi Swami: An Intellectual Biography\" />

column2: Indian independence]] Bodheswaran gradually withdrew from active politics, although he remained a Congressman until his death. He lectured and wrote on the subject of Swamikal, his belief as quoted by Nair and Devi is that Swamikal was \"an embodiment of perfect knowledge\".<ref name=\"Chattampi Swami: An Intellectual Biography\" />

column1: Bodheswaran was known for his poems reflecting nationalistic fervour during his involvement in the [[Indian independence movement]] which included ''Keralaganam'', a popular patriotic song of the times.<ref name=\"Bodheswaran - Kerala Literature\" /><ref name=\"Singh2015\">{{cite book
column3: title=How Solidarity Works for Welfare: Subnationalism and Social Development in India
column8: pages=85–}}</ref> He published six books which, besides poetry anthologies, include a compilation of his speeches.<ref name=\"List of works\">{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2019-04-08}}</ref> He attempted to write a comprehensive world history covering the period up to [[World War I]] but could not complete it. ''Suprabhatham'', a amagazine he founded, also had only a short life.<ref name=\"Biography on Kerala Sahitya Akademi portal\" />

column1: The Government of India honoured him with the ''Thamra Patra'' (Copper Plaque) for his contributions to the Indian independence movement.<ref name=\"Biography on Kerala Sahitya Akademi portal\" /> His birth centenary was celebrated in 2002 when [[K. R. Narayanan]], the then president of India, inaugurated ''Bodheshwaran Foundation'', an eponymous organization, for propagating his ideals.<ref name=\"Bodheswaran foundation inaugurated - Times of India\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Bodheswaran foundation inaugurated - Times of India
column5: access-date=2019-04-08}}</ref> ''Keralaganam'', his patriotic song, was declared as the cultural song of Kerala in 2014.<ref name=\"Bodheswaran - Kerala Literature\" />

column3: title=Poetry - The Second Generation of Romantics
column4: publisher=Information & Public Relations Department, Government of Kerala

column3: title=Portrait commissioned by Kerala Sahitya Akademi
title=Jayajaya Komala Kerala - By Jayachandran and Madhuri from National Songs (Album)

column4: The \"Black Sunday\" dust storm approaches [[Spearman, Texas

column1: '''Black Sunday''' refers to a particularly severe [[dust storm]] that occurred on April 14, 1935, as part of the [[Dust Bowl]].<ref name=\"nws\">{{cite web
column2: title=The Black Sunday Dust Storm of 14 April 1935
column4: publisher=National Weather Service: Norman, Oklahoma Weather Forecast Office
column5: accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> It was one of the worst dust storms in American history and it caused immense economic and agricultural damage.<ref name=\"pbs\">{{cite web
column9: accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> It is estimated to have displaced 300 million tons of [[topsoil]] from the prairie area in the US.<ref>''Black Blizzard'', History Channel documentary.</ref>

column1: On the afternoon of April 14, the residents of the [[Plains States]] were forced to take cover as a dust storm, or \"black blizzard\", blew through the region. The storm hit the [[Oklahoma Panhandle]] and [[Northwestern Oklahoma]] first, and moved south for the remainder of the day.<ref name=\"nws\"/> It hit [[Beaver, Oklahoma
column3: Boise City]] around 5:15 p.m., and [[Amarillo, Texas]], at 7:20 p.m.<ref name=\"nws\"/> The conditions were the most severe in the Oklahoma and [[Texas panhandle]]s, but the storm's effects were felt in other surrounding areas.<ref name=\"nws\"/>

column1: The storm was harsh due to the high winds that hit the area that day. The combination of drought, erosion, bare soil, and winds caused the dust to fly freely and at high speeds.<ref name=\"ncdc\">{{cite web
column4: work=Drought: A Paleo Perspective -- 20th Century Drought

column1: In North America, the term \"Dust Bowl\" was first used to describe a series of dust storms that hit the [[prairie]]s of [[Canada]] and the [[United States]] during the 1930s,<ref name=\"ncdc\"/> and later to describe the area in the United States that was most affected by the storms, including western Kansas, eastern Colorado, northeastern New Mexico, and the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles.<ref name=\"histevents\">{{cite web
column4: work=Historic Events for Students: The Great Depression

column1: The \"black blizzards\" started in the Eastern states in 1930, affecting agriculture from [[Maine]] to [[Arkansas]]. By 1934 they had reached the [[Great Plains]], stretching from North Dakota to Texas, and from the [[Mississippi embayment
column2: Mississippi River Valley]] to the [[Rocky Mountains]].<ref name=\"watkins\">{{cite book
column9: pages=162–170}}</ref> \"The Dust Bowl\" (as an area) received its name following the disastrous \"Black Sunday\" storm in April 1935, when reporter Robert E. Geiger referred to the region as \"The Dust Bowl\" in his account of the storm.<ref name=\"histevents\"/>

column2: sheep ranching]] had left much of the West devoid of natural grass and shrubs to anchor the soil,<ref name=\"histevents\"/> and over-farming and poor soil stewardship left the soil dehydrated and lacking in organic matter.<ref name=\"watkins\"/> During a massive [[drought]] that hit the United States in the 1930s,<ref name=\"histevents\"/> the lack of rainfall, snowfall, and moisture in the air dried out the top soil in most of the country's farming regions.

column1: The destruction caused by the dust storms, and especially by the storm on Black Sunday, killed multiple people {{Citation needed
column2: date=April 2018}} and caused hundreds of thousands of people to relocate.<ref name=\"watkins\"/> Poor migrants from the American Southwest (known as \"[[Okie]]s\" - though only about 20 percent were from Oklahoma) flooded California, overtaxing the state's health and employment infrastructure.<ref name=\"howstuffworks\">{{cite web

column1: In 1935, after the massive damage caused by these storms, Congress passed the [[Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act of 1936
column2: Soil Conservation Act]], which established the [[Natural Resources Conservation Service
column3: Soil Conservation Service]] (SCS) as a permanent agency of the [[United States Department of Agriculture
column8: accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> The SCS was created in an attempt to provide guidance for land owners and land users to reduce soil erosion, improve forest and field land and conserve and develop natural resources.<ref name=\"howstuffworks\"/><ref>{{cite web
column15: archivedate=14 February 2013 }}</ref>  This led to the [[Great Plains Shelterbelt]] project.

column1: == Personal accounts of Black Sunday and other dust storms ==

During the 1930s, many residents of the Dust Bowl kept accounts and journals of their lives and of the storms that hit their areas. Collections of accounts of the dust storms during the 1930s have been compiled over the years and are now available in book collections and online.

column2: text=\"People caught in their own yards grope for the doorstep. Cars come to a standstill, for no light in the world can penetrate that swirling murk…. The nightmare is deepest during the storms. But on the occasional bright day and the usual gray day we cannot shake from it. We live with the dust, eat it, sleep with it, watch it strip us of possessions and the hope of possessions.\"<ref name=\"pbs\"/>

column1: Lawrence Svobida was a [[wheat]] farmer in Kansas during the 1930s.<ref name=\"histevents\"/>  He experienced the period of dust storms, and the effect that they had on the surrounding environment and the society.<ref name=\"histevents\"/> His observations and feelings are available in his memoirs, ''Farming the Dust Bowl''.<ref name=\"histevents\"/> Here he describes an approaching dust storm:

column2: text=\"… At other times a cloud is seen to be approaching from a distance of many miles. Already it has the banked appearance of a cumulus cloud, but it is black instead of white and it hangs low, seeming to hug the earth. Instead of being slow to change its form, it appears to be rolling on itself from the crest downward. As it sweeps onward, the landscape is progressively blotted out. Birds fly in terror before the storm, and only those that are strong of wing may escape. The smaller birds fly until they are exhausted, then fall to the ground, to share the fate of the thousands of jack rabbits which perish from suffocation.\"<ref name=\"histevents\"/>}}

column1: The Black Sunday storm is detailed in the 2012 [[Ken Burns]] PBS documentary ''[[The Dust Bowl (film)

Musicians and songwriters began to reflect the Dust Bowl and the events of the 1930s in their music. [[Woody Guthrie]], a singer-songwriter from Oklahoma, wrote a variety of songs documenting his experiences living during the era of dust storms.<ref name=\"nws\"/> Several were collected in his first album ''[[Dust Bowl Ballads]]''. One of them, ''Great Dust Storm'', describes the events of Black Sunday.  An excerpt of the lyrics follows:
''There struck the worst of dust storms that ever filled the sky.
''You could see that dust storm comin', the cloud looked deathlike black,
''And through our mighty nation, it left a dreadful track.
''From Oklahoma City to the Arizona line,
''Dakota and Nebraska to the lazy Rio Grande,
''It fell across our city like a curtain of black rolled down,
''We thought it was our judgement, we thought it was our doom.<ref name=\"nws\"/>

Musician Kat Eggleston has written a play, ''The Cyclone Line'', about her father Al Eggleston's experiences growing up in 1930s Oklahoma, Black Sunday, and the Dust Bowl in general. Its first public performances were on [[Vashon, Washington
column2: Vashon (Island), Washington]], where he lived most of his life.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=The Cyclone Line, a play by Kat Eggleston « Vashon Center for the Arts

column1: Americana recording artist [[Grant Maloy Smith]] released an album in 2017 called ''Dust Bowl – American Stories'' that featured two songs that directly referenced Black Sunday. The song \"Old Black Roller\" is written from a first person perspective during the Black Sunday storm, and another song \"Never Seen The Rain\" has these chorus lyrics: \"We worked the land to death, me and my brother
column3: Oklahoma, you were like our mother - oh, my\"

column1: American recording artist [[Gillian Welch]] refers to the storm and other historical events in a two-part song on her 2001 album ''[[Time (The Revelator)]]'': \"April the 14th Part I\" and \"Ruination Day Part II\".
[[Category:1935 natural disasters in the United States]]

A '''ball mill''' is a type of [[grinder (milling)
column2: grinder]] used to grind, blend and sometimes for mixing of materials for use in mineral dressing processes, paints, pyrotechnics, ceramics and [[selective laser sintering]].  It works on the principle of  impact and  attrition: size reduction is done by impact as the balls drop from near the top of the shell.

column1: A ball mill consists of a hollow cylindrical shell rotating about its axis.  The axis of the shell may be either horizontal or at a small angle to the horizontal.  It is partially filled with balls.  The grinding media are the balls, which may be made of steel ([[chrome steel]]), stainless steel, ceramic or rubber.  The inner surface of the cylindrical shell is usually lined with an abrasion-resistant material such as [[Mangalloy
column2: manganese steel]] or [http://sakarrubtech.com/mill-lining.php rubber lining].  Less wear takes place in rubber lined mills.  The length of the mill is approximately equal to its diameter.

column1: The general idea behind the ball mill is an ancient one, but it was not until the [[industrial revolution]] and the invention of [[steam power]] that an effective ball milling machine could be built.  It is reported to have been used for grinding flint for pottery in 1870.<ref>{{cite book

In case of continuously operated ball mill, the material to be ground is fed from the left through a 60° cone and the product is discharged through a 30° cone to the right. As the shell rotates, the balls are lifted up on the rising side of the shell and then they cascade down (or drop down on to the feed), from near the top of the shell. In doing so, the solid particles in between the balls and ground are reduced in size by impact.

The ball mill is used for grinding materials such as coal, pigments, and feldspar for pottery. Grinding can be carried out either wet or dry but the former is performed at low speed. Blending of explosives is an example of an application for rubber balls.<ref name=\"TM_9-1300-214_p10-8\">{{Citation
column3: title=Department of the Army technical manual: military explosives (TM 9-1300-214)
column6: postscript=.}}</ref> For systems with multiple components, ball milling has been shown to be effective in increasing [[solid-state chemistry
column10: title=Self-sustaining reactions induced by ball milling
column16: doi=10.1016/S0079-6425(01)00002-0}}</ref> Additionally, ball milling has been shown effective for production of amorphous materials. <ref>{{cite journal
column19: title=Self-sustaining reactions induced by ball milling

column1: A ball mill, a type of [[grinder (milling)
column2: grinder]], is a cylindrical device used in grinding (or mixing) materials like [[ores]], chemicals, ceramic raw materials and paints. Ball mills rotate around a horizontal axis, partially filled with the material to be ground plus the grinding medium. Different materials are used as media, including [[ceramic]] balls, [[flint]] pebbles and [[stainless steel]] balls. An internal cascading effect reduces the material to a fine powder. Industrial ball mills can operate continuously, fed at one end and discharged at the other end. Large to medium-sized ball mills are mechanically rotated on their axis, but small ones normally consist of a cylindrical capped container that sits on two drive shafts ([[pulleys]] and belts are used to transmit rotary motion). A [[rock tumbler]] functions on the same principle.  Ball mills are also used in [[pyrotechnics]] and the manufacture of [[black powder]], but cannot be used in the preparation of some pyrotechnic mixtures such as [[flash powder]] because of their sensitivity to impact. High-quality ball mills are potentially expensive and can grind mixture particles to as small as 5 [[Nanometre
column3: nm]], enormously increasing surface area and reaction rates.

column1: The grinding works on the principle of critical speed.  Critical speed can be understood as that speed after which the steel balls (which are responsible for the grinding of particles) start rotating along the direction of the cylindrical device; thus causing no further grinding.
Ball mills are used extensively in the [[mechanical alloying]] process<ref>

column4: title=Comparative study of Al-Ni-Mo alloys obtained by mechanical alloying in different ball mills
column9: display-authors=etal}}</ref> in which they are not only used for grinding but for cold welding as well, with the purpose of producing alloys from powders.<ref>[http://www.imp.mtu.edu/webform/index.htm Mechanical Alloying Technology], Institute of Materials Processing</ref>

column1: [[Image:Marcy Ball Mill - Shenandoah-Dives Mill, 135 County Road 2, Silverton, San Juan County, CO HAER CO-91 (sheet 21 of 27) (cropped).png
column5: A section cut thru of ball mills]]

column1: The ball mill is a key piece of equipment for grinding crushed materials, and it is widely used in production lines for powders such as cement, silicates, refractory material, fertilizer, glass ceramics, etc. as well as for [[Mineral processing
column2: ore dressing]] of both ferrous and non-ferrous metals. The ball mill can grind various ores and other materials either wet or dry. There are two kinds of ball mill, grate type and overfall type due to different ways of discharging material.  Many types of grinding media are suitable for use in a ball mill, each material having its own specific properties and advantages.  Key properties of grinding media are size, density, hardness, and composition.

column1: * Size: The smaller the media particles, the smaller the particle size of the final product.  At the same time, the grinding media particles should be substantially larger than the largest pieces of material to be ground.
* Density: The media should be denser than the material being ground.  It becomes a problem if the grinding media floats on top of the material to be ground.
* Hardness: The grinding media needs to be durable enough to grind the material, but where possible should not be so tough that it also wears down the tumbler at a fast pace.

* Composition: Various grinding applications have special requirements.  Some of these requirements are based on the fact that some of the grinding media will be in the finished product.  Others are based in how the media will react with the material being ground.
* Where the color of the finished product is important, the color and material of the grinding media must be considered.

* Where low contamination is important, the grinding media may be selected for ease of separation from the finished product (i.e.: steel dust produced from stainless steel media can be magnetically separated from non-ferrous products).  An alternative to separation is to use media of the same material as the product being ground.
* Flammable products have a tendency to become [[dust explosion
column2: explosive in powder form]].  Steel media may spark, becoming an ignition source for these products.  Either wet-grinding, or non-sparking media such as [[ceramic]] or [[lead]] must be selected.

column1: * Some media, such as iron, may react with corrosive materials.  For this reason, [[stainless steel]], ceramic, and [[flint]] grinding media may each be used when corrosive substances are present during grinding.

The grinding chamber can also be filled with an inert [[shield gas]] that does not react with the material being ground, to prevent oxidation or explosive reactions that could occur with ambient air inside the mill.
[[File:Ceramic ball mill before 1945 Thiem and Towe Halle.jpg
column4: Halle]]. Property of Faculty of Chemistry, Gdańsk University of Technology]]

column1: Ball milling boasts several advantages over other systems: the cost of installation and grinding medium is low; it is suitable for both batch and continuous operation, similarly it is suitable for open as well as closed circuit grinding and is applicable for materials of all degrees of hardness.

Aside from common ball mills there is a second type of ball mill called a ''planetary ball mill''. Planetary ball mills are smaller than common ball mills and mainly used in laboratories for grinding sample material down to very small sizes. A planetary ball mill consists of at least one grinding jar which is arranged eccentrically on a so-called sun wheel. The direction of movement of the sun wheel is opposite to that of the grinding jars (ratio: 1:-2 or 1:-1).

The grinding balls in the grinding jars are subjected to superimposed rotational movements, the so-called Coriolis forces. The difference in speeds between the balls and grinding jars produces an interaction between frictional and impact forces, which releases high dynamic energies. The interplay between these forces produces the high and very effective degree of size reduction of the planetary ball mill.

The interplay between these forces produces the high and very effective degree of size reduction of the planetary ball mill.

column17: general]] during the [[Peloponnesian War]]. He was the first prominent representative of the commercial class in Athenian politics, although he was an [[Aristocracy (class)
column18: aristocrat]] himself. His contemporaries, the historian [[Thucydides]] and the comedic playwright [[Aristophanes]], both represent him as an unscrupulous, warmongering [[demagogue]], but both of them had strong motives to present Cleon unfavorably.

column1: Cleon first came to notice as an opponent of [[Pericles]] in the late 430s BCE through his opposition to Pericles' strategy of refusing battle against the [[Peloponnesian League]] invaders in 431 BCE.  As a result, he found himself acting in concert with the Athenian aristocratic parties, who also had no liking for Pericles. During 430 BCE, after the unsuccessful expedition by Pericles to the [[Peloponnese
column2: Peloponnesus]], and when the city was devastated by the [[Plague of Athens
column3: plague]], Cleon headed the opposition to Pericles' rule. At this time, Pericles was accused by Cleon of maladministration of public money, with the result of Pericles being found guilty and removed from office.<ref>[[George Grote]]. ''History of Greece'', abridged ed., 1907, p. 406, note 1</ref> However, Pericles' setback was temporary and he was soon reinstated.

column1: The death of Pericles from the plague in 429 BCE left the field clear for new leadership in Athens. Hitherto Cleon had only been a vigorous opposition speaker, a trenchant critic and accuser of state officials, but he now came forward as the professed champion and leader of the [[democracy]] and rapidly came to dominate Athenian politics.  Although rough and unpolished, he was charismatic, with natural eloquence and a powerful voice, and he knew how to work upon the emotions of the Athenian populace. He strengthened his support amongst the poorer citizens by increasing the pay for jury work, which provided a livelihood for many of the poorer Athenians.
The fondness of the Athenians for litigation increased his power; and the practice of \"[[sycophant
column2: sycophancy]]\" (raking up material for false charges) enabled him to remove those who were likely to endanger his ascendancy. In 426 BCE, Cleon brought an unsuccessful prosecution against [[Laches (person)
column4: generalship]] in the unsuccessful first Sicilian expedition.  This is one of the very few times that an Athenian general escaped civil punishment for a defeat.  Having no further use for his former aristocratic associates, he broke off all connection with them, and thus felt at liberty to attack the secret combinations for political purposes, the oligarchical clubs to which they mostly belonged. Whether he also introduced a property-tax for military purposes, and even held a high position connected with the treasury, is uncertain.

column1: Cleon's ruling principles were an inveterate hatred of the nobility, and an equal hatred of Sparta. It was mainly through him that the opportunity of concluding an honourable peace (in 425 BCE) was lost, and in his determination to see [[Sparta]] defeated, often spoke of dazzling future benefits. He insisted upon Athenian security via strategic possession of territories rather than by Spartan goodwill.<ref>{{Cite book

In 427 BCE, Cleon urged his Athenian countrymen to put to death the whole adult male population of [[Mytilene]], which had put itself at the head of a revolt. His proposal, though at first accepted, was soon rescinded due to a protracted rebuttal by [[Diodotus (son of Eucrates)
column2: Diodotus]]. Nonetheless approximately one thousand chief leaders and prominent men of Mytilene were executed. In 425 BCE, Cleon reached the summit of his fame by capturing and transporting to Athens the Spartans who had been blockaded at the [[Battle of Sphacteria]]. Much of the credit was probably due to the military skill of his colleague [[Demosthenes (general)
column3: Demosthenes]] (not the orator); but it was due to Cleon's determination that the [[ecclesia (ancient Athens)
column4: Ecclesia]] sent out the additional force that was needed.

column1: It was almost certainly due to Cleon that the tribute of the \"allies\" was doubled in 425 BCE. In 422 BCE he was sent to recapture [[Amphipolis]], but was outmaneuvered by the Spartan general [[Brasidas]]. However, both Brasidas and Cleon were killed at Amphipolis and their deaths removed the chief obstacle to peace. Thus, in 421 BCE the [[peace of Nicias]] was signed.

The character of Cleon is represented by [[Aristophanes]]<ref>Cf. Aristophanes, chiefly ''[[The Knights]]'' (864–867: \"You are like the fishers for eels; in still waters they catch nothing, but if they thoroughly stir up the slime, their fishing is good; in the same way it's only in troublous times that you line your pockets.\", etc.), ''[[The Wasps]]'' (esp. 664–712), and most mentions of Cleon in the other plays.</ref> and [[Thucydides]]<ref>Cf. Thucydides, ''[[History of the Peloponnesian War]]'', book III (36: \"the most violent man at Athens\", and 37–40 on the Mytilene affair), IV (21: \"a popular leader of the time and very powerful with the multitude\", 22, 27–29 on the Pylos affair), and V (16: \"Cleon and Brasidas, who had been the two principal opponents of peace on either side—the latter from the success and honour which war gave him, the former because he thought that, if tranquillity were restored, his crimes would be more open to detection and his slanders less credited\").</ref> in a very unfavourable light. Their portrayals may be justified considering he instilled a feeling of mistrust within Athens through a kind of Athenian \"[[McCarthyism]]\", caused by the excessive number of informants he employed to keep watch on the city. Yet, both have been suspected of being prejudiced witnesses: The playwright Aristophanes had a grudge against Cleon, who may have accused him before the Council of having ridiculed (in his lost play ''Babylonians'') the policy and institutions of his city in the presence of foreigners and at the time of a great national danger. Thucydides, believing in the shortcomings of democratic government,<ref>A.H.M. Jones, ‘The Athenian democracy and its critics’, ''Cambridge Historical Journey''. 11.1 (1953), 1–26.</ref> had also been prosecuted (unjustly, his ships arriving two days after a town was occupied by Spartan forces) for military incapacity and exiled by a decree proposed by Cleon. Indeed, of all the persons who appear in Thucydides' ''History'', Cleon is treated with the least impartiality.<ref>[[Zagorin, Perez]]. ''Thucydides.'' (Princeton University Press, 2015), p. 80</ref> It is therefore possible that Cleon has had injustice done to him in the portraits handed down by these two writers.<ref>\"Cleon\", ''Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition'', vol. IV, p. 495</ref>

His influence lay in his forceful and bullying style of oratory, anti-intellectual and anti-aristocratic in tone, and his [[populism]]. This might have brought him many enemies. He seems to have aimed at short-term goals, but Athens' poor stood to benefit by his policies, at the expense of heavy taxes levied onto her allies.<ref>\"Cleon\", ''Oxford Companion to Classical Literature'', edited by M.C. Howatson and Ian Chilvers, Oxford University Press</ref>

For the literature on Cleon see [[Karl Friedrich Hermann]], ''Lehrbuch der griechischen Antiquitäten'', i. pt. 2 (6th ed. by V. Thumser, 1892), p. 709, and [[Georg Busolt]], ''Griechische Geschichte'', iii. pt. 2 (1904), p. 988, note 3.
The following are the chief authorities:

column2: C. F. Ranke]], ''De Aristophanis Vita Commentatio'' (Leipzig, 1845)
J. G. Droysen]], ''Aristophanes'', ii., ''Introd. to the Knights'' (Berlin, 1837)
H. Müller-Strübing]], ''Aristophanes und die historisehe Kritik'' (Leipzig, 1873)
J. F. Kortüm]], ''Geschichtliche Forschungen'' (Leipzig, 1863), and ''Zur Geschichte hellenichen Statsverfassungen'' (Heidelberg, 1821)
E. Curtius]], ''History of Greece'' (Eng. tr. iii. p. 112)
E. Meyer]], ''Forschungen zur alten Geschichte'', ii. p. 333 (Halle, 1899)
K. J. Beloch]], ''Die attische Politik seit Perikles'' (Leipzig, 1884), and ''Griechische Geschichte'', i. p. 537
A. Holm]], ''History of Greece'', ii. (Eng. tr.), ch. 23, with the notes.
H. Bengtson]], ''History of Greece: From the Beginnings to the Byzantine Era'', Cleon p. 140

Polish]] [[volleyball]] team based in [[Gdańsk]]. In 2008 the club debuted in the highest level Polish volleyball men's league, [[PlusLiga]]. In the seasons 2009/2010 and 2010/2011 the club played in the first league, and in 2011 they returned to [[PlusLiga]].<ref>[http://www.sport.trefl.com/siatkowka/aktualnosci/?title=Jeste%C5%9Bmy+w+PlusLidze!+Lotos+Trefl+Gda%C5%84sk+-+Jadar+Radom+3%3A0&news_id=9474&extra-param=1 ''Jesteśmy w PlusLidze! Lotos Trefl Gdańsk - Jadar Radom 3:0''] – sport.trefl.com – 01-05-2011</ref> Their home matches are being played at the [[Ergo Arena]].

column1: In the 2013/2014 season, LOTOS Trefl coach was [[Radosław Panas]].<ref>[http://www.sport.trefl.com/siatkowka/aktualnosci/?title=Rados%C5%82aw+Panas+odchodzi+z+LOTOSU+Trefla&news_id=14604&extra-param=1 ''Radosław Panas odchodzi z LOTOSU Trefla''] – sport.trefl.com – 09-04-2014</ref> During his work as a main coach the team won 9 times and lost 11 matches. The club didn't play in the [[PlusLiga]] play-offs and ended the season 2013/2014 on 10th place.<ref>[http://www.sport.trefl.com/siatkowka/aktualnosci/?title=LOTOS+Trefl+efektownie+zamkn%C4%85%C5%82+sezon&news_id=14577&extra-param=1 ''LOTOS Trefl efektownie zamknął sezon''] – sport.trefl.com – 05-04-2014</ref> In June 2014, the Italian [[Andrea Anastasi]] was officially presented as the club's new coach.<ref>[http://www.sport.trefl.com/siatkowka/aktualnosci/?title=Andrea+Anastasi+trenerem+LOTOSU+Trefla+Gda%C5%84sk&news_id=14901&extra-param=1 ''Andrea Anastasi trenerem LOTOSU Trefla Gdańsk''] – sport.trefl.com – 05-06-2014</ref><ref>[http://www.plusliga.pl/news/id/9291 ''Andrea Anastasi trenerem LOTOSU Trefla Gdańsk''] – plusliga.pl – 05-06-2014</ref> Anastasi was a head coach of the [[Poland men's national volleyball team
column2: Polish national team]] in 2011-2013 and expressed a desire to work for the club from Gdańsk. New players [[Damian Schulz]]<ref>[http://www.sport.trefl.com/siatkowka/aktualnosci/?title=Damian+Schulz+graczem+LOTOSU+Trefla&news_id=14925&extra-param=1 ''Damian Schulz graczem LOTOSU Trefla''] – sport.trefl.com – 11-06-2014</ref>, [[Mateusz Mika]]<ref>[http://www.sport.trefl.com/siatkowka/aktualnosci/?title=Mateusz+Mika+wraca+do+Gda%C5%84ska&news_id=14954&extra-param=1 ''Mateusz Mika wraca do Gdańska''] – sport.trefl.com – 18-06-2014</ref>, [[Wojciech Grzyb]] signed a contract with the club before 2014/2015 season.<ref>[http://www.sport.trefl.com/siatkowka/aktualnosci/?title=Wojciech+Grzyb+wzmacnia+gda%C5%84ski+blok&news_id=14974&extra-param=1 ''Wojciech Grzyb wzmacnia gdański blok''] – sport.trefl.com – 24-06-2014</ref> Team took 3rd place in regular season of [[2014–15 PlusLiga
column4: Anastasi]]'s team won 19 and lost 7 matches. On 23 February 2015 [[Andrea Anastasi]] signed new two-years contract, because of good results in regular season till 2017.<ref>[http://www.plusliga.pl/news/id/10786 ''Andrea Anastasi poprowadzi LOTOS Trefl przez kolejne dwa lata''] – plusliga.pl – 23-02-2015</ref> LOTOS Trefl advanced to the final of [[2014–15 PlusLiga]] after winning in semifinal against Polish Champion [[PGE Skra Bełchatów]] (in the competition to three wins, result was 3-1). It was the first, historical promotion to the final of Polish Championship.<ref>[http://www.sportowefakty.pl/siatkowka/512424/piekny-sen-gdanszczan-trwa-belchatowianie-nie-obronia-tytulu-relacja-z-meczu-lot ''Piękny sen gdańszczan trwa! Bełchatowianie nie obronią tytułu - relacja z meczu Lotos Trefl Gdańsk - PGE Skra Bełchatów''] – sportowefakty.pl – 04-04-2015</ref>
