column1: '''Cooter''' is a city in [[Pemiscot County, Missouri
column2: Pemiscot County]], [[Missouri]], United States. The population was 469 at the [[2010 United States Census

column1: According to Houck's History of Missouri, the town of Cooter was named in 1854 for the Madame Coutre, the owner of a brothel that served travelers that passed through the Missouri Bootheel. Madame Coutre is believed to have emigrated from [[France]] in the mid-1700s to the Franco-American village of [[Ste. Genevieve, Missouri
column2: Ste. Genevieve, Missouri]]. Marie Coutre travelled inland westward, and in 1795 is listed in documents as being a merchant and tavern owner in the area of present-day Cooter.

column1: She was famous for her extra large vaginal labia that were sought out by riverboat crewmen looking for company. It was due to her renown vagina that cooter entered American English as a slang word. Samuel Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, was said to have paid for \"some cooter\" at least four times during his career as a riverboat pilot. Madame Marie Coutre ran the brothel until her death in 1812. Her daughter, Joan Cooter, took over the family business, which lasted five generations.

The Cooter Tavern Inn was shutdown in 1929 by a crack team of FBI agents enforcing Prohibition laws. The brothel was demolished, but the town retains the name of its legendary founder.<ref>A History of Missouri Vol. 2, by Louis Houck. Published by R.R. Donnelley & Sons, Chicago, 1908.{{quotation requested

Cooter is located in the southeast corner of the [[Missouri Bootheel]] on [[Missouri Route E]] 1.5 miles east of [[I-55]]. The Missouri-[[Arkansas]] border is three miles to the south and the [[Mississippi River]] lies six miles east.<ref>''Missouri Atlas & Gazetteer,'' DeLorme, 1st ed. 1998, p. 71 {{isbn
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert

column5: accessdate=2012-07-08}}</ref> of 2010, there were 469 people, 175 households, and 133 families living in the city. The [[population density]] was {{convert
column9: 1}}. There were 191 housing units at an average density of {{convert
column13: 1}}. The racial makeup of the city was 97.87% [[White (U.S. Census)
column16: African American]], and 0.21% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column18: Latino]] of any race were 0.43% of the population.

column1: There were 175 households of which 45.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 49.7% were [[Marriage
column2: married couples]] living together, 19.4% had a female householder with no husband present, 6.9% had a male householder with no wife present, and 24.0% were non-families. 19.4% of all households were made up of individuals and 10.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.68 and the average family size was 3.05.

column1: The median age in the city was 35.5 years. 28.4% of residents were under the age of 18; 8.2% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 28.1% were from 25 to 44; 22.9% were from 45 to 64; and 12.4% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.4% male and 51.6% female.

column1: In the city the population was spread out with 25.2% under the age of 18, 8.6% from 18 to 24, 26.6% from 25 to 44, 22.5% from 45 to 64, and 17.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37 years. For every 100 females there were 96.4 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.0 males.

The median income for a household in the city was $28,750, and the median income for a family was $32,955. Males had a median income of $26,429 versus $18,500 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $13,267. About 16.1% of families and 20.6% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 18.8% of those under age 18 and 19.2% of those age 65 or over.

February,safe,Unoquha,"[[File:James Hay, 1st Earl of Carlisle from NPG.jpg
'''James Hay, 1st Earl of Carlisle''' [[Order of the Bath
A Scot, he was the son of Sir James Hay of Fingask, second son of Peter Hay of [[Megginch Castle
column2: Megginch]] (a branch member of Hay of Leys, a younger branch of the Erroll family) and his wife Margaret, daughter of Crichton of Ruthven.<ref name=JS>[https://digital.nls.uk/histories-of-scottish-families/archive/95428023?mode=transcription ''Historical Account of the Family of Hay of Leys''], (Edinburgh, 1832), pp. 20-1. Accessed January 2020.</ref> His mother was Margaret Murray, cousin of [[George Hay, 1st Earl of Kinnoull
column3: George Hay]], afterwards [[George Hay, 1st Earl of Kinnoull

column1: His aunts married well and had two well regarded uncles. His uncle Peter Hay of Megginch married Margaret Ogilvie, daughter of Sir Patrick Ogilvie of Inch, and are the ancestors of the later [[Earls of Kinnoull]] via their son, his first cousin Peter of Kirklands of Megginch.<ref name=JS /> His uncle Edmund Hay was Professor of Scots Law at [[University_of_Douai

He was knighted and taken into favour by [[James VI of Scotland]], brought into England in 1603, treated as a \"prime favourite\" and made a gentleman of the bedchamber. In 1604, he was sent on a mission to France and pleaded for the Huguenots, which annoyed [[Henry IV of France]] and caused a substantial reduction of the present made to the English envoy. On 21 June 1606, he was created by patent a baron for life with precedence next to the barons, but without a place or voice in [[Parliament of England
column2: Parliament]], no doubt to render his advancement less unpalatable to the English lords.{{sfn

column1: The king bestowed on him numerous grants, paid his debts, and secured for him a rich bride in the person of Honoria, only daughter and heir of [[Edward Denny, 1st Earl of Norwich
column2: Edward, Lord Denny]]. Their marriage was celebrated by ''[[Lord Hay's Masque]],'' staged on 6 January 1607. On 9 February 1608 he performed in the masque ''[[The Hue and Cry After Cupid]]'' at [[Whitehall Palace]] as a sign of the zodiac, to celebrate the wedding of [[John Ramsay, 1st Earl of Holderness
column3: John Ramsay, Viscount Haddington]] to Elizabeth Radclyffe.<ref>Edmund Lodge, ''Illustrations of British History'', vol. 3 (London, 1838), p. 223.</ref> In 1610 he was made a knight of the [[Order of the Bath]], and in 1613 master of the wardrobe, while in 1615 he was created Lord Hay of [[Sawley, Lancashire
column4: Sawley]], and took his seat in the [[House of Lords]]. At this time, his first wife Honora was buried 16 August 1614 at Waltham Abbey.  He was sent to France next year to negotiate the marriage of Princess Christina with [[Charles I of England
column5: Prince Charles]], and on his return, being now a widower, he was made a [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom

column1: In February 1617 he presented a masque by [[Ben Jonson]], ''[[Lovers Made Men]]'', to the French ambassador [[Charles Cauchon de Maupas
column2: Baron de Tour]] at his house in London. The performance was staged by the [[Lucy Russell, Countess of Bedford
column3: Countess of Bedford]] and said to have cost £2200.<ref>Norman Egbert McClure, ''The Letters of John Chamberlain'', vol. 2 (Philadelphia, 1939), pp. 51, 55, 57.</ref> Later that year, he married Lady Lucy Percy (1599–1660), daughter of [[Henry Percy, 9th Earl of Northumberland]] (the famous \"Wizard Earl\"), by his wife [[Dorothy Percy, Countess of Northumberland

column1: [[File:Coat of arms of Sir James Hay, 1st Earl of Carlisle, KG.png
column4: Coat of arms of Sir James Hay, 1st Earl of Carlisle, KG]]

column1: In 1618 he resigned the mastership of the wardrobe for a large sum in compensation. He was created Viscount Doncaster, and in February 1619 was despatched on a mission to [[Kingdom of Germany
column2: Germany]], where during the beginning [[Thirty Years' War]] he identified himself with the cause of the \"Winter King\", Elector [[Frederick V of the Palatinate]], and urged James to make war in his support. In 1621 and 1622 he was sent to [[Kingdom of France
column3: France]] to obtain peace for the [[Huguenots]] from [[Louis XIII of France
column4: Louis XIII]], in which he was unsuccessful, and in September 1622 was created [[Earl of Carlisle]].{{sfn

column1: Next year he went to [[Paris]] on the occasion of Prince Charles's journey to [[Madrid]], and again in 1624 to join [[Henry Rich, 1st Earl of Holland
column2: Henry Rich]], afterwards Lord Holland, in negotiating the prince's marriage with [[Henrietta Maria]], when he advised James without success to resist [[Cardinal Richelieu
column3: Richelieu]]'s demands on the subject of religious toleration.{{sfn
column6: p=339}} In 1624 he was made a knight of the [[Order of the Garter]]. Charles's marriage in 1625 was [[Proxy marriage
column7: by proxy]], so the wedding contract was signed by Carlisle and Holland. The king's representative at the actual wedding was [[Claude de Lorraine, Duke of Chevreuse
column8: the duke of Chevreuse]], yet Carlisle and Holland acted as witnesses.{{Citation needed

column1: Carlisle became gentleman of the bedchamber to [[Charles I of England
column2: King Charles I]] after his accession. In 1628, after the failure of the expedition to [[Isle of Rhe
column3: Rhe]], he was sent to make a diversion against [[Cardinal Richelieu]] in [[Lorraine (province)
column5: Piedmont]]; he counselled peace with Spain and the vigorous prosecution of the war with France, but on his return home found his advice neglected. He took no further part in public life, and died in March 1636.{{sfn

column1: Carlisle was a man of good sense and of accommodating temper, with some diplomatic ability. His extravagance and lavish expenditure, his double suppers and costly entertainments, were the theme of satirists and wonder of society, and his debts were said at his death to amount to more than £80,000. He left behind him, says [[Edward Hyde, 1st Earl of Clarendon
column2: Clarendon]], a reputation of a very fine gentleman and a most accomplished courtier, and after having spent, in a very jovial life, above £400,000, which upon a strict computation he received from the crown, he left not a house or acre of land to be remembered by.{{sfn

column1: Hay by 1612 was a director of the [[Virginia Company]].<ref>Schreiber, p. 168.</ref> He was a patentee and councillor of the plantation of [[New England]], and showed great interest in the colonies.{{sfn

Carlise also had an interest in the Caribbean. There [[James Ley, 1st Earl of Marlborough]] was a rival, who had to be bought off.<ref>Schreiber, p. 170.</ref> Another rival was the [[Philip Herbert, 4th Earl of Pembroke
column6: last=Schreiber}}</ref> On 2 July 1627 Carlisle obtained from the king a [[Proprietary colony
column7: grant]] of all the [[Caribbean Islands]], including [[Barbados]], this being a confirmation of a former concession given by [[James I of England
column11: p=339}} A colonial plantation venture on Barbados was led in 1628 by [[Marmaduke Roydon]], a prominent [[City of London]] merchant and one of Carlisle's major creditors.<ref>{{cite ODNB

column1: Hay's first wife was Honoria Denny. His second wife, [[Lucy Hay, Countess of Carlisle]], was involved in many conspiracies, or allegations thereof, during the [[English Civil War]].{{sfn

The first earl was succeeded by James, his only surviving son by his first wife.  James married Margaret Russell, third daughter of [[Francis Russell, 4th Earl of Bedford]], but James died without issue on 30 October 1660. At his death, the peerage became extinct in the Hay family.{{sfn
column4: p=340}} The Hay Family currently spans across the world.{{Citation needed

column1: *Roy E. Schreiber, ''The First Carlisle Sir James Hay, First Earl of Carlisle as Courtier, Diplomat and Entrepreneur, 1580-1636'', Transactions of the American Philosophical Society New Series, Vol. 74, No. 7 (1984), pp. 1–202. Published by: American Philosophical Society. Stable URL: https://www.jstor.org/stable/1006420.

column2: title=Bagatelle Great House, Restaurant and Wine Bar and Lord Willoughby's Tavern officially open

column3: French]]: ''Troisième circonscription de la Loire'') is a French legislative [[Constituency (France)
column4: constituency]] in the Loire ''[[Departments of France
column5: département]]''. Like the other 576 French constituencies, it elects one [[National Assembly of France
column7: first past the post]] election system with a run-off.

column2: Loire]] lies to the east of [[Saint-Etienne]] in the south of the department. The largest town in the constituency [[Saint-Chamond, Loire
column3: Saint-Chamond]] sits on the main road between Saint-Etienne and [[Lyon]].

column1: Between its creation in its modern form in 1988 and 2017 the seat was represented by [[François Rochebloine]] of the centre right. He finally lost his seat to [[La République En Marche!
column2: En Marche!]] in the landslide election of that year.

column2: singles]] and [[music video]]s releasing in 2020, by British [[virtual band]] [[Gorillaz]]. The project marks the first release with [[Remi Kabaka Jr.]] as an official band member,<ref>{{cite AV media
column12: publisher=Gorillaz}}</ref> as well as the return of the character [[Murdoc Niccals]] in promotional material, after his absence from ''[[The Now Now]]'' in 2018. The project began with \"[[Momentary Bliss]]\", which featured rapper [[Slowthai]] & punk rock band [[Slaves (UK band)
column13: Slaves]], on 30 January, and is expected to continue until the end of the year.<ref name=\"nastylittleman1\">{{cite web

column1: On 28 January, the band officially released images via social media teasing a concept entitled ''Song Machine''.  A 23-second promotional single entitled \"Song Machine Theme Tune\" was released on streaming services with an accompanying video.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Gorillaz Are Teasing Something Called 'Song Machine'

column2: Remi Kabaka]] spoke to [[BBC Radio 1]]'s [[Annie Mac]] for the official premiere, saying that ''Song Machine'' \"may have an obtuse narrative arc at the end of each season, but it's more ''[[Ozark (TV series)
column4: Designated Survivor]]''. You just keep going until you run out of ideas.\"<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Gorillaz Debut 'Song Machine' Series With 'Momentary Bliss'
column13: title=Gorillaz unveil 'Momentary Bliss' video, featuring slowthai and Slaves

column1: Upon the premiere of \"Momentary Bliss\", Albarn revealed that the group had been in the studio with [[ScHoolboy Q]] and [[Sampa the Great]] among others, although he did say that these songs were likely to be saved for future series of ''Song Machine''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Radio 1's Future Sounds with Annie Mac - Gorillaz, slowthai and Slaves - BBC Sounds
column6: accessdate=2020-02-27}}</ref> The group also teased a possible collaboration with Australian band [[Tame Impala]] on [[Instagram]].<ref>[https://www.nme.com/news/music/gorillaz-tease-tame-impala-collaboration-as-song-machine-project-continues-2603985]{{dead link

column1: A press release was put out to explain Song Machine further, with virtual Gorillaz member Russel Hobbs saying: \"''Song Machine'' is a whole new way of doing what we do, Gorillaz breaking the mould 'cos the mould got old. World is moving faster than a supercharged particle, so we’ve gotta stay ready to drop. We don’t even know who's stepping through the studio next. ''Song Machine'' feeds on the unknown, runs on pure chaos. So whatever the hell’s coming, we’re primed and ready to produce like there’s no tomorrow.\"<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Song Machine: Gorillaz team up with Slowthai and Slaves for new online series

column3: カラフィナ}} was a Japanese vocal group formed by the composer [[Yuki Kajiura]] in 2007, mainly to perform theme songs for the anime ''[[Kara no Kyōkai]]''.

column1: The group first appeared in January 2008 with two original members from Yuki Kajiura's [[FictionJunction]] project, Wakana Ōtaki and Keiko Kubota, whose membership was not confirmed until the first Dream Port 2008 concert held on April 29, 2008. In May 2008, it was announced that two more vocalists, Maya and Hikaru, would be added to the project. Kalafina moved to the Sacra Music record label under Sony Music Entertainment Japan in April 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=ソニー、新レーベル『SACRA MUSIC』4月発足 Kalafina、ClariSら擁し海外展開

column1: With Yuki Kajiura leaving her agency Space Craft Produce in 2018, news agency [[Oricon]] reported that the group was expected to continue even with Kajiura leaving.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Anime Music Composer Yuki Kajiura Leaves Agency After 25 Years
column8: title=アニメ業界で事務所トラブル　梶浦由記氏退社、カラフィナも活動休止へ　20億円超の打撃
column13: title=アニメ音楽界のカリスマ・梶浦由記氏事務所退社、「カラフィナ」活動は白紙
column16: access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref> Space Craft has further announced that concerts, 10th anniversary film's plans are still moving forward.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column18: title=Singing Unit Kalafina to Continue After Producer Yuki Kajiura's Departure
column25: title=Kalafina、プロデューサー梶浦氏退社後も活動継続
column30: access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref> However, they are expected to disband in Spring,<ref>{{cite web
column31: title=Kalafina disbanding at the end of Spring {{!}} ARAMA! JAPAN
column35: date=13 March 2018}}</ref> although Space Craft reported to the official fan club that only one member will leave Kalafina.<ref>{{Cite web
column37: title=Singing Unit Kalafina's Agency Confirms 1 Member Will Leave
column42: title=システムメンテナンスのお知らせ
column47: title =Kalafina Harmony Fanclub Message(Translate from the official site of Kalafina Harmony Fanclub)
column50: accessdate=March 13, 2018}}</ref> Although rumors said that Hikaru would leave the group, Sports Hochi reported that the member that will leave the group is Keiko, and that official news about who is leaving the group would be announced at the end of March 2018.<ref>{{Cite web
column52: title=「Ｋａｌａｆｉｎａ」脱退メンバーはＫｅｉｋｏ　今秋予定のＣＤ＆ツアーは白紙に
column55: access-date=March 14, 2018}}</ref> It was confirmed on April 13, 2018 on Kalafina Lineblog that Keiko had officially left the group as of April 1, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web
column60: access-date=April 13, 2018}}</ref> Following this, Hikaru left the agency as of October 20, 2018, although she not stated that she left the group. Finally, on March 13, 2019, Space Craft announced Kalafina's disbandment.<ref>{{Cite web
column62: title=Harmony会員の皆様へお知らせ

column7: born December 5, 1985}}<!--- birthdate from JP wikipedia ---> (2007–2018): Like Wakana, she is also a member of Kajiura's [[FictionJunction]] project and worked alongside her under the name FictionJunction KEIKO. She officially left the group on April 1, 2018.
born December 10, 1984}}<!--- birthdate from JP wikipedia ---> (2007–2019): She is also a member of [[FictionJunction]] and previously collaborated with Yuki Kajiura as FictionJunction WAKANA.

column1: * '''Maya Toyoshima''' (豊島摩耶 ''Toyoshima Maya'')  (2008–2009): Was selected in an audition held by Sony Music Japan. She left the group in 2009.

column7: born July 2, 1987}} (2008–2018): Was picked from 30,000 applicants in an audition held by [[Sony Music Japan]]. She officially left Space Craft on October 20, 2018.

column1: * '''[[Yuki Kajiura]]''' (2007–2018): Formerly the primary composer and arranger of Kalafina's songs.  Kajiura left the group upon her departure from Space Craft Produce.<ref name=\":0\" />
* '''REMI''' (田中玲美 ''Tanaka Remi'', born January 6, 1977): Background vocalist.
* '''Yuriko Kaida''' (貝田由里子 ''Kaida Yuriko,'' born November 1): Background vocalist.
* '''Hanae Tomaru''' (戸丸華江, ''Tomaru Hanae''): Background vocalist.
* 2016: ''Kalafina 8th Anniversary Special products The Live Album「Kalafina LIVE TOUR 2014」at TOKYO INTERNATIONAL FORUM HALL A'' (live)

'''Werner Krolikowski''' (born 12 March 1928 <ref>[https://www.chronikderwende.de/lexikon/biografien/biographie_jsp/key=krolikowski_werner.html Chronik der Wende: Werner Krolikowski]</ref>) is an [[East Germany
column2: East German]] political official who became a senior politician. He was a member of the Central Committee of the ruling [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column3: SED (party)]] politburo and a deputy chairman of the national [[Council of Ministers of the GDR
column9: title=Krolikowski, Werner * 12.3.1928 Mitglied des Politbüros des ZK der SED, 1. Stellv. des Vorsitzenden des Ministerrats
column10: publisher= Bundesstiftung zur Aufarbeitung der SED-Diktatur: Biographische Datenbanken
column11: accessdate= 25 November 2014}}</ref> He also produced a number of political publications.

column1: Werner Krolikowski was born into a working-class family.   He trained for office work.   By the time the [[Second world war
column2: war]] ended the frontier between Poland and Germany had [[Oder-Neisse line
column3: moved west]] and Krolikowski, along with millions of other Germans, [[Flight and expulsion of Germans from Poland during and after World War II
column4: had also moved]], the town of his birth now being part of Poland.  In 1946 he joined the newly formed [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column5: Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED / ''Sozialistische Einheitspartei Deutschlands'')]] in the [[Soviet occupation zone]] of what was left of Germany.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/>

column1: He worked till 1950 for the council in the [[Malchin]] district, some 75 km (40 miles) south-east of [[Rostock]], then from 1951 till 1952 for the regional [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column2: party]] leadership at [[Mecklenburg]].  In 1952 he was appointed First secretary of the party district leadership at [[Ribnitz-Damgarten]] on the north coast.   Then, in December 1952, he was relieved of his functions \"on account of gross breach of party rules\".<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/><ref>''\"wegen grober Verletzung des Parteistatuts\"''</ref>

column1: Nevertheless, between 1953 and 1958 he was second and then first secretary to the [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column2: party]] district leadership at [[Greifswald]], then till 1960 he was secretary for [[Agitprop
column3: Agitation and Propaganda]] for the party district leadership in the [[Rostock]] region in succession to [[:de:Karl Zylla
column4: Karl Zylla]]<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/> before, in 1973, moving to the other end of the country and taking a position as First Secretary of the [[Dresden]] district leadership, where his predecessor had been [[:de:Fritz Reuter (Politiker)

column1: In 1963 Krolikowski became a member of the Party Central Committee, and in 1970 he became a member of the national [[People's Chamber
column2: People's Chamber ''(\"Volkskammer\")'']],<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/> where his responsibilities included membership of the assembly's National Defence Committee.   In 1971 he joined the party politburo's central committee.   Between 1973 and 1976 he was Secretary of the Party's Central Committee, and from 1976 right up till 1989 he was a member of the Economics Commission and of Central Committee Working Groups on the Balance of Payments and on inter-German Economic Relations.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/>   From 1976 till 1988 he was First Deputy Chairman of the [[German Democratic Republic]]'s [[Council of Ministers of the GDR
column3: Ministerial Council]].   In 1988, following the sudden death of [[:de:Werner Felfe
column4: Werner Felfe]] (who had suffered the misfortune to be identified in western media as a possible successor to [[Erich Honecker
column5: First Secretary Erich Honecker)]] Krolikowski regained the Central Committee secretaryship for agriculture.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/>

column2: The Wall came down.]]  In November 1989 Werner Krolikowski resigned from his various public offices and on 3 December 1989 he was expelled from what had till very recently been the unchallenged [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column3: ruling party]] in [[East Germany]].   An investigation was launched, based on \"suspicions of abuse of office and corruption\" (''\"Verdachts auf Amtsmißbrauch u. Korruption\"'').   In May 1990 he was charged with \"misappropriation of state funds\" (''\"Veruntreuung von Staatsgeldern\"'') and arrested before being released on bail.   However, the case was dropped on health grounds.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/>

column1: The extent to which [[East Germany]]'s leader [[Erich Honecker]] and his inner circle felt unsettled and undermined by on-going [[Perestroika]] in the [[Soviet Union]] became more widely known after Honecker himself had retired.   The Soviet ambassador in [[East Berlin]] from 1983 till 1990 was a man called [[Vyacheslav Kochemasov]], a diplomat whose experience of politics in [[Moscow]] and in [[East Berlin]] went back a long way.   He gave an interview to the western press in 1992 in which he disclosed that as far back as 1986 Werner Krolikowski had told him, in confidence, that the situation in the [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column2: SED]] Politburo had become \"unbearable\":  policy decisions were totally driven by dogma, there was no longer any discussion, there was an absurd level of centralisation and an utterly implausible communications strategy.  Something must be done:  the leader must be replaced.<ref name=spiegel471992> {{cite web
column6: title=Schmeichelei und Unterwürfigkeit  SPIEGEL-Interview mit Moskaus Ex-Botschafter in der DDR, Wjatscheslaw Kotschemassow, über Erich Honecker

column1: Werner Krolikowski's elder brother, [[Herbert Krolikowski]] (1924-2012) was also an East German politician of eminence.   Herbert never rose quite as far as Werner, but he did serve as East Germany's deputy foreign minister between 1963 and 1967 and again between 1975 and 1990.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenHK>{{cite web
column6: title=Krolikowski, Herbert  * 15.3.1924, † 28.11.2012  Stellv. Minister für Auswärtige Angelegenheiten
column7: publisher= Bundesstiftung zur Aufarbeitung der SED-Diktatur: Biographische Datenbanken

column1: After 1966 the \"[[Patriotic Order of Merit]]\", which Krolikowski received \" ([[:de:Für Verdienste um Volk und Vaterland
column2: \"for services to the people and the fatherland\" (''\"Für Verdienste um Volk und Vaterland\"'')]] was awarded at three different levels, designated respectively bronze, silver and gold, so that particularly long standing providers of exceptional service not infrequently won it more than once.

column1: * ''Zu einigen Fragen der Führungstätigkeit der Kreisleitungen der SED'', Berlin 1972
* ''Der Kampf um die Verwirklichung der vom VIII. Parteitag beschlossenen Hauptaufgabe und die Bedeutung des wissenschaftlich-technischen Fortschritts'', Berlin 1974
* ''Zu einigen Grundfragen der Wirtschaftspolitik der Sozialistischen Einheitspartei Deutschlands unter dem besonderen Blickpunkt der 13. Tagung des ZK der SED'', Berlin 1975
* ''Der IX. Parteitag der SED über die Fortsetzung des politischen Kurses der Hauptaufgabe. Die Einheit von Wirtschafts- und Sozialpolitik'', Berlin 1976
* ''Die Intensivierung der gesellschaftlichen Produktion. Hauptweg der wirtschaftlichen Entwicklung der DDR'', Leipzig 1977
* ''Die Verantwortung der sozialistischen Staatsmacht bei der Verwirklichung der Wirtschaftsstrategie des X. Parteitages der SED'', Potsdam 1983
* ''DDR. Bollwerk des Sozialismus und Hort des Friedens'', Potsdam 1984
* ''Je stärker der Sozialismus - desto sicherer der Frieden. Ausgewählte Reden und Aufsätze.'', Berlin 1988

column2: The Wall came down.]]  In November 1989 Werner Krolikowski resigned from his various public offices and on 3 December 1989 he was expelled from what had till very recently been the unchallenged [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column3: ruling party]] in [[East Germany]].   An investigation was launched, based on \"suspicions of abuse of office and corruption\" (''\"Verdachts auf Amtsmißbrauch u. Korruption\"'').   In May 1990 he was charged with \"misappropriation of state funds\" (''\"Veruntreuung von Staatsgeldern\"'') and arrested before being released on bail.   However, the case was dropped on health grounds.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenWK/>

column1: The extent to which [[East Germany]]'s leader [[Erich Honecker]] and his inner circle felt unsettled and undermined by on-going [[Perestroika]] in the [[Soviet Union]] became more widely known after Honecker himself had retired.   The Soviet ambassador in [[East Berlin]] from 1983 till 1990 was a man called [[Vyacheslav Kochemasov]], a diplomat whose experience of politics in [[Moscow]] and in [[East Berlin]] went back a long way.   He gave an interview to the western press in 1992 in which he disclosed that as far back as 1986 Werner Krolikowski had told him, in confidence, that the situation in the [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany
column2: SED]] Politburo had become \"unbearable\":  policy decisions were totally driven by dogma, there was no longer any discussion, there was an absurd level of centralisation and an utterly implausible communications strategy.  Something must be done:  the leader must be replaced.<ref name=spiegel471992> {{cite web
column6: title=Schmeichelei und Unterwürfigkeit  SPIEGEL-Interview mit Moskaus Ex-Botschafter in der DDR, Wjatscheslaw Kotschemassow, über Erich Honecker

column1: Werner Krolikowski's elder brother, [[Herbert Krolikowski]] (1924-2012) was also an East German politician of eminence.   Herbert never rose quite as far as Werner, but he did serve as East Germany's deputy foreign minister between 1963 and 1967 and again between 1975 and 1990.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenHK>{{cite web
column6: title=Krolikowski, Herbert  * 15.3.1924, † 28.11.2012  Stellv. Minister für Auswärtige Angelegenheiten
column7: publisher= Bundesstiftung zur Aufarbeitung der SED-Diktatur: Biographische Datenbanken

column1: After 1966 the \"[[Patriotic Order of Merit]]\", which Krolikowski received \" ([[:de:Für Verdienste um Volk und Vaterland
column2: \"for services to the people and the fatherland\" (''\"Für Verdienste um Volk und Vaterland\"'')]] was awarded at three different levels, designated respectively bronze, silver and gold, so that particularly long standing providers of exceptional service not infrequently won it more than once.

column2: singles]] and [[music video]]s releasing in 2020, by British [[virtual band]] [[Gorillaz]]. The project marks the first release with [[Remi Kabaka Jr.]] as an official band member,<ref>{{cite AV media
column12: publisher=Gorillaz}}</ref> as well as the return of the character [[Murdoc Niccals]] in promotional material, after his absence from ''[[The Now Now]]'' in 2018. The project began with \"[[Momentary Bliss]]\", which featured rapper [[Slowthai]] & punk rock band [[Slaves (UK band)
column13: Slaves]], on 30 January, and is expected to continue until the end of the year.<ref name=\"nastylittleman1\">{{cite web

column1: On 28 January, the band officially released images via social media teasing a concept entitled ''Song Machine''.  A 23-second promotional single entitled \"Song Machine Theme Tune\" was released on streaming services with an accompanying video.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Gorillaz Are Teasing Something Called 'Song Machine'

column2: Remi Kabaka]] spoke to [[BBC Radio 1]]'s [[Annie Mac]] for the official premiere, saying that ''Song Machine'' \"may have an obtuse narrative arc at the end of each season, but it's more ''[[Ozark (TV series)
column4: Designated Survivor]]''. You just keep going until you run out of ideas.\"<ref>{{cite web

column1: Upon the premiere of \"Momentary Bliss\", Albarn revealed that the group had been in the studio with [[ScHoolboy Q]] and [[Sampa the Great]] among others, although he did say that these songs were likely to be saved for future series of ''Song Machine''.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Radio 1's Future Sounds with Annie Mac - Gorillaz, slowthai and Slaves - BBC Sounds
column6: accessdate=2020-02-27}}</ref> The group also teased a possible collaboration with Australian band [[Tame Impala]] on [[Instagram]].<ref>[https://www.nme.com/news/music/gorillaz-tease-tame-impala-collaboration-as-song-machine-project-continues-2603985]{{dead link

column1: A press release was put out to explain Song Machine further, with virtual Gorillaz member Russel Hobbs saying: \"''Song Machine'' is a whole new way of doing what we do, Gorillaz breaking the mould 'cos the mould got old. World is moving faster than a supercharged particle, so we’ve gotta stay ready to drop. We don’t even know who's stepping through the studio next. ''Song Machine'' feeds on the unknown, runs on pure chaos. So whatever the hell’s coming, we’re primed and ready to produce like there’s no tomorrow.\"<ref>{{cite web

column1: Until recently, most studies on [[time travel]] are based upon [[classical physics
column2: classical]] [[general relativity]]. Coming up with a quantum version of time travel requires us to figure out the time evolution equations for [[density state]]s in the presence of [[closed timelike curve]]s (CTC).
title        = Cauchy problem in spacetimes with closed timelike curves

column1: </ref> had conjectured that once quantum mechanics is taken into account, [[Novikov self-consistency principle
column2: self-consistent]] solutions always exist for all time machine configurations, and initial conditions. However, it has been noted such solutions are not unique in general, in violation of [[determinism]], [[unitarity]] and [[linearity]].

column1: The application of self-consistency to quantum mechanical time machines has taken two main routes. [[Novikov self-consistency principle
column2: Novikov's rule]] applied to the density matrix itself gives the Deutsch prescription. Applied instead to the state vector, the same rule gives nonunitary physics with a dual description in terms of post-selection.
Deutsch's prescription not involving the many worlds interpretation
title        = Quantum mechanics near closed timelike lines

column1: </ref> came up with a proposal for the time evolution equations, with special note as to how it resolves the [[grandfather paradox]] and nondeterminism. However, his resolution to the grandfather paradox is considered unsatisfactory to some people, because it states the time traveller reenters another [[Many-worlds interpretation
column2: parallel universe]], and that the actual [[quantum state]] is a [[quantum superposition]] of states where the time traveller does and does not exist.

column1: He made the simplifying assumption that we can split the quantum system into a subsystem A external to the closed timelike curve, and a CTC part. Also, he assumed that we can combine all the time evolution between the exterior and the CTC into a single [[unitary operator]] ''U''. This presupposes the [[Schrödinger picture]]. We have a [[tensor product]] for the combined state of both systems. He makes the further assumption there is no correlation between the initial density state of A and the density state of the CTC. This assumption is not time-symmetric, which he tried to justify by appealing to measurement theory and the second law of thermodynamics. He proposed that the density state restricted to the CTC is a fixed-point of

column2: fixed points]] always exist. He justified this choice by noting the [[expectation value]] of any CTC observable will match after a loop. However, this could lead to \"multivalued\" histories if memory is preserved around the loop. In particular, his prescription is incompatible with [[path integral formulation
column3: path integrals]] unless we allow for multivalued fields. Another point to note is in general, we have more than one fixed point, and this leads to [[Indeterminism
column4: nondeterminism]] in the time evolution. He suggested the solution use is the one with the [[maximum entropy principle
column5: maximum entropy]]. The final external state is given by <math>\\text{Tr}_{\\text{CTC}} \\left[ U \\left( \\rho_A \\otimes \\rho_{\\text{CTC}} \\right) U^\\dagger\\right]</math>. Pure states can evolve into mixed states.

column1: This leads to seemingly paradoxical resolutions to the grandfather paradox. Assume the external subsystem is irrelevant, and only a qubit travels in the CTC. Also, assume during the course around the time machine, the value of the qubit is flipped according to the unitary operator
The most general fixed-point solution is given by

where ''a'' is a real number between <math>-1/2</math> and <math>1/2</math>. This is an example of the nonuniqueness of solutions. The solution maximizing the [[von Neumann entropy]] is given by <math>a=0</math>. We can think of this as a mixture (not superposition) between the states <math>\\left( \\left
column5: 1 \\right\\rangle \\right)/\\sqrt{2}</math>. This leads to an interesting interpretation that if the qubit starts off with a value of 0, it will end up with a value of 1, and vice versa, but this should not be problematic according to Deutsch because the qubit ends up in a different parallel universe in the [[many worlds interpretation]].

column1: Later researchers have noted that if his prescription turned out to be right, computers in the vicinity of a time machine can solve [[PSPACE-complete]] problems.<ref>{{cite journal

column2: title        = Closed Timelike Curves Make Quantum and Classical Computing Equivalent
journal      = Proceedings of the Royal Society

column1: However, it was shown in an article by Tolksdorf and Verch that Deutsch's CTC fixed point condition can be fulfilled to arbitrary precision in any quantum system described according to relativistic [[quantum field theory]] on spacetimes where CTCs are excluded, casting doubts on whether Deutsch's condition is really characteristic of quantum processes mimicking CTCs in the sense of [[general relativity]].<ref>{{cite journal

column2: title        = Quantum physics, fields and closed timelike curves: The D-CTC condition in quantum field theory

column2: title        = Closed Timelike Curves via Postselection: Theory and Experimental Test of Consistency
title        = The quantum mechanics of time travel through post-selected teleportation

column1: }}</ref> based upon [[post-selection]] and path integrals. In particular, the path integral is over single-valued fields, leading to self-consistent histories. He assumed it is ill-defined to speak of the actual density state of the CTC itself, and we should only focus upon the density state outside the CTC. His proposal for the time evolution of the external density state is

If <math>\\text{Tr}\\left[ C\\rho_i C^\\dagger\\right]=0</math>, no solution exists due to [[destructive interference]] in the path integral. For instance, the grandfather paradox has no solution, and leads to an inconsistent state. If a solution exists, it is clearly unique. Now, [[quantum computer]]s using time machines can only solve [[PP (complexity)#Complete problems and other properties
A related description of CTC physics was given in 2001 by Michael Devin, and applied to thermodynamics.<ref>{{cite thesis

}}</ref> The same model with the introduction of a noise term allowing for inexact periodicity, allows the grandfather paradox to be resolved, and clarifies the computational power of a time machine assisted computer. Each time traveling qubit has an associated [[negentropy]], given approximately by the logarithm of the noise of the communication channel. Each use of the time machine can be used to extract as much work from a thermal bath. In a brute force search for a randomly generated password, the entropy of the unknown string can be effectively reduced by a similar amount. Because the negentropy and computational power diverge as the noise term goes to zero, complexity class may not be the best way to describe the capabilities of time machines.
